","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of Takataka Plastics. ","italic":true}]}]

title: New Zealand’s capital of self-sufficiency
subtitle: What can we learn from Great Barrier Island.
author: Jasmine Balloch
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Great Barrier Island (Māori - Aotea) sits a four-hour ferry ride from Auckland and a view away from the Coromandel peninsula. The natural beauty of this island is endless; it’s a certified dark sky sanctuary and predator-free refuge for endangered birds with a heavy scattering of beaches, mountains and untouched bush. The Barrier is completely off-grid - thanks to its sheer remoteness and rough terrain. It has been noted for leading New Zealand in the use of solar power with the largest off-grid solar panel system in the country. With the majority of its homes powered by this resource, concern for the environment is right at the heart of what Great Barrier Island stands for. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I spent the month of March on the island, staying with a couple who needed help around the house and garden. I lived in a home where water and electricity were harvested commodities and waste barely existed. Leftovers were consumed the following day, scraps fed to the chickens, cardboard boxes used for a worm farm, plastic milk bottles stuffed with non-recyclable plastics to use as bricks and glass jars repurposed to hold homemade condiments. The potential for copious amounts of household and garden waste diminished to less than a small grocery bag per week for five to six adults.  To accompany this education in rubbish reduction, my stay coincided with a 100 day stretch without rain; I quickly learnt the absurdity of letting water go down a sink. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"My hosts’ ingenuity with respect to waste is a real example to be followed – as is the island’s approach to environmental preservation in general. Look at "},{"type":"link","url":"http://protectaotea.online/","children":[{"text":"Protect Aotea"}]},{"text":":  a local organisation opposing the dumping of marine waste from Auckland harbours. The island has borne the brunt of the practice - essentially a cheap but unsustainable fix - for many years. However, residents did not take lightly to a proposed five times yearly increase in sediment dumping.  In December, protesters succeeded in winning two appeals at the High Court in Wellington, and have thus seen the plans effectively cancelled. The ruling came as a relief to local "},{"text":"iwi","italic":true},{"text":" members, concerned with preserving the Barrier for future generations."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589626085/Screen_Shot_2020-05-16_at_11.47.00_tsoavw.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Community allows the Barrier to thrive. The acquisition of fish is just one example: fresh fish cannot be purchased on the island, so you must be a keen fisherman or know one if you want to have fresh fish for dinner. This has created a barter-type system, where home grown veg or a DIY helping hand may be exchanged for said fish. To add to this, little public transport and the price of fuel has normalised the practice of hitchhiking; the local church ‘Opp Shop’ is known as the place to go for donating unwanted items; and the food waste from the pub is donated to feed the chickens. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Island living can make everyday actions a little harder, but it foregrounds the consequences of all our actions within conscious thought. All rubbish and recycling must be transported to Auckland and supplies are delivered from there too, resulting in a collective push to be mindful of food usage and waste production. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Repurposing waste and sourcing a portion of food locally - through growing it or buying close to home – is a first step to being more self-sufficient. As we spend more time at home through this pandemic, we’re all noticing how much waste even just one household produces. Now can be the opportunity to reinvent what we do with it, taking inspiration from around the world – starting at Great Barrier Island. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589626288/Screen_Shot_2020-05-16_at_11.46.37_mm5lap.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But can something that’s effective on an island of 1000 inhabitants really be employed in heavily-populated cities? Yes, if we call for a redesign of the system to further encompass the circular economy. As we come out of the coronavirus pandemic, we will see a unique opportunity to set this in motion. A circular economy model brings with it the creation of new jobs and industry – a priority if we are to move forward from this crisis with environmental concern at the forefront."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Two main messages can be taken from the Barrier and those who call it home: "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Protect what is yours. Fight for the preservation of your home, safeguarding it for future generations. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Living more self-sufficiently and sustainably is possible, and can work alongside a thriving economy  – if we’re willing to put the effort in. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jasmine Balloch is about to start an Msc in Control of Infectious Diseases at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. She has worked at the University of Arizona. ","italic":true}]}]

title: One step at a time
subtitle: Ethical footwear brand Flamingos’ Life is a fashionable force for good
author: Abi Malins
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Brought up in the family business of footwear, Carlos García Sánchez always knew his own venture would revolve around social and environmental responsibility. In 2015, he founded "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/","children":[{"text":"Flamingos’ Life"}]},{"text":", an ecologically and ethically conscious footwear brand."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Organic, pesticide-free cotton, recycled plastic waste, natural corn residue and sustainably sourced rubber are handcrafted into Flamingos’ trainers, with absolutely no animal products involved. As the brand has developed, it’s also committed to tackling specific environmental and social issues with each new collection it releases."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Take the Roland design, for example. Working in collaboration with the Brussels-based NGO Waste Free Oceans, local fishermen, recycling companies and political bodies, Flamingos’ Life is aiming to reduce, reuse and recycle plastic waste that’s polluting the world’s waters. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“Five days before the [Spanish] state of emergency was announced we decided to work from home. It’s been really simple to adapt, with the technology available we’ve been able to keep all departments running at 100%,” says Carlos. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Each pair of Roland shoes contains roughly two recycled plastic bottles, giving polluting, wildlife-endangering plastic new life as a conscious fashion item. To date, the brand’s recycled "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/pages/rsc-oceans","children":[{"text":"over 21,000"}]},{"text":" plastic bottles. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The company’s most recent Rancho collection marks its move into using natural hemp, a material known for its low water consumption during growth, durability, and high CO2 absorption rate. “All that makes it an ideal alternative to leather or plastic, [which are] far more polluting,” Carlos tells me. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589830383/Screen_Shot_2020-05-18_at_20.32.40_bd2dxg.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Roland shoe. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For each Rancho pair that’s bought, Flamingos’ plants 5 trees in collaboration with NGO Eden Reforestation Projects. The joint initiative focuses on reforesting areas of Madagascar and Mozambique to preserve precious mangrove ecosystems, revive natural habitats for rare wildlife and provide local employment opportunities. Currently, the results stand at some "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/pages/rsc-reforestation","children":[{"text":"124,800 trees planted and 3,990 working hours "}]},{"text":"generated. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carlos’ pro-environment convictions are adamant: “We’re literally killing the planet. We’ve been doing it for 50 years but the authorities concerned haven’t been aware or haven’t wanted to take sides.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As well as promoting environmentally conscious fashion practices, Flamingos’ is holding the questionable ethics of the fashion industry to account. Fast fashion prioritises profit over fair payment and worker wellbeing, particularly as major brands outsource manufacturing to less wealthy areas of the world. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2018, Flamingos’ took the decision to recentralise the brand’s entire production process. Moving manufacturing from Asia back to Carlos’ local city of Elche in southeastern Spain was an important step towards ensuring total transparency within the company’s supply chain. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Producing their trainers using local, artisanal and ethically sound Spanish companies ensures there’s no exploitation within Flamingos’ production processes. By arranging local suppliers for everything from textiles to shoeboxes, they’re also reducing their carbon footprint further. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Flamingos’ recent collaboration with sustainable fashion consultancy "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bcomestudio.com/","children":[{"text":"BCOME"}]},{"text":" has confirmed fair working conditions across its entire supply chain, from growing raw materials to cutting the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/pages/rsc-manufacture","children":[{"text":"trainers’ signature ‘F’s"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Scaling down to local production was a multi-impact decision at the time, reinforcing the brand’s climate-conscious and ethical approach. One additional, unforeseen element of that change is its direct impact on Flamingos’ ability to stay up and running during coronavirus lockdown. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589830550/OCEANS-03_l4qwo9.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Working towards waste-free oceans. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Five days before the [Spanish] state of emergency was announced we decided to work from home. It’s been really simple to adapt, with the technology available we’ve been able to keep all departments running at 100%,” says Carlos. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Asked how the pandemic has affected the brand’s sustainability goals, Carlos is clear that there’s a lot the fashion sector, as well as society at large, can learn from this unprecedented situation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We can take positive lessons from the pandemic (with all due respect and empathy towards those who have suffered or whose relatives have fallen ill). We have to ask ourselves if the life we were leading was the right one to be healthy and happy.”"}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“I think the role of the state is going to become fundamental to enabling us to save the planet in the coming years. It’s an effort all institutions have to make: state, businesses and consumers, all for one.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carlos has been following the positive environmental impact of lockdown closely, as dramatic reductions in air, sea and road travel – for both goods and people – has had a significant effect. “It’s let the planet breathe,” he says. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But for real change to come from this crisis, there needs to be a consciously collaborative effort to change the priorities of regulating authorities, fashion companies and consumers, Carlos tells me. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I think the role of the state is going to become fundamental to enabling us to save the planet in the coming years. It’s an effort all institutions have to make: state, businesses and consumers, all for one.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Abi Malins is a writer and translator based in Amsterdam. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/AbiMalins","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]}]

title: Level the playing field
subtitle: We need to tackle inequality to adequately tackle the climate crisis.
author: Lucy Pearson
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We’re all experiencing the Covid-19 pandemic. However, it is clear that some are feeling the effects more than others. Put succinctly; "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/politics/article/coronavirus-bame?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=1590164625","children":[{"text":"‘the coronavirus does not discriminate…society does’"}]},{"text":". We are each living out our own version of lockdown. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Before the virus emerged, the uneven distribution of income in the UK was already a big issue. In 2018, the ONS "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/personalandhouseholdfinances/incomeandwealth/datasets/householddisposableincomeandinequality","children":[{"text":"found"}]},{"text":" that the poorest fifth held only 8% of the total income, whereas the top fifth held 40%. This disparity is, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/may/04/coronavirus-equal-society-britain-wellbeing-economic-growth","children":[{"text":"according to Richard Wilkinson and Kate Pickett"}]},{"text":" - the authors of "},{"text":"The Spirit Level ","italic":true},{"text":"- 'likely to have widened rather than narrowed during the crisis, as the low-paid lose sources of income while high-earners who work at home continue to draw salaries'. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Unless action is taken, what we’re seeing now will impact many generations to come. It is affecting our youngest already. With schools shut, Teach First - where I work - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.teachfirst.org.uk/shut-in-not-shut-out","children":[{"text":"have highlighted"}]},{"text":" that the educational inequality gap is only likely to extend, as children with no access to internet, printers, or laptops struggle to learn at home, while the children of high-earners continue to have opportunities to study. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1590743990/neonbrand-zFSo6bnZJTw-unsplash_rwbd8v.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The educational inequality gap is likely to extend. Image courtesy of NeONBRAND. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The pandemic is also shedding light on links between racial inequality and public health provision in the UK. The risk of Covid-19 related death amongst BAME people is significantly higher than in those of white ethnicity groups. Black men and women are "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/birthsdeathsandmarriages/deaths/articles/coronavirusrelateddeathsbyethnicgroupenglandandwales/2march2020to10april2020#main-points","children":[{"text":"over four times more likely"}]},{"text":" to die than white ethnicity men and women. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We know that BAME people are more likely to experience deprivation and live in overcrowded housing”, says Dr Chaaned Nagpaul of the BMA, “which impacts their health and that a greater number are in key worker roles, which lessens the chance of being able to socially distance.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nagpaul "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bma.org.uk/news-and-opinion/deeply-worrying-ons-data-highlights-need-to-protect-bame-communities-from-covid-19-warns-bma","children":[{"text":"recognises"}]},{"text":" there are likely to be multiple factors behind the findings – but it’s clear that “social and economic reasons” play a substantial part, if not the largest role, in this disparity between numbers of deaths. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Evidently, this pandemic is not a leveller. So how come the feeling that ‘we’re all in this together’ is resonating so much across the nation? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Being in the same predicament creates unity and shared interests”, say Wilkinson and Pickett. Exemplifying this is the NHS volunteer scheme; a million signed up – four times the amount anticipated. Civic gestures like this have kept that feeling of togetherness alive, emulating the effects of a more equal society. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1590743231/k-mitch-hodge-VVqDTBCK5pY-unsplash_gfso0q.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://unsplash.com/photos/VVqDTBCK5pY","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"text":"Civic gestures keep the feeling of togetherness alive. Image courtesy of K. Mitch Hodge. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We will need to harness this feeling, and work towards levelling the playing field in terms of social inequality, when we turn to face the next crisis: climate change. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Covid-19 has given us a chance to reflect and change, but once we reach the other side, we have to act collectively and quickly if we are to ensure our planet is not damaged further. Just like Covid-19, climate change also emphasises and perpetuates inequalities. Intrinsically linked to economic inequality, it is driven by the greenhouse gas emissions of the wealthiest, and hits the poorest - particularly those in the Global South - the hardest. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There is a strong correlation between the wealth of a person and their production of global emissions. It is the poorest half of the world’s population – around 3.5 billion people – that live overwhelmingly in the countries most susceptible to climate change. This is despite only being responsible for roughly 10% of global emissions. In comparison, the world’s richest 10% are responsible for around 50% of global emissions.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The richest citizens should be encouraged to slash their own emissions, but voluntary action will only go so far in slowing emissions. Governments need to do more - and fast. If they fail to intervene, the only winners will be those with vested interests in fossil fuel activities, and an extremely lopsided global economy will persist. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By ironing out inequalities within their own nations, they’ll create more eco-friendly societies. Wilkinson and Pickett, in "},{"text":"The Spirit Level","italic":true},{"text":",  examine how greater equality not only increases social wellbeing and lessens health and social problems, but also enables countries to do better when it comes to environmental protection. How? There is a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.fabians.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/A-Convenient-Truth.pdf","children":[{"text":"striking link "}]},{"text":"between more equal societies and stronger community life. Amongst these populations is a greater sense of public good, as egocentric attitudes lessen and reciprocity increases. This leads to a clearer view of humanity ‘as one’, and encourages collective climate action accordingly. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1590743871/richard_2_g7phl5.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Richard Wilkinson talks climate. Image courtesy of The Equality Trust. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And when it comes to global politics, previous international agreements have taught us that - in order to benefit the common good - the poorest will have to be at the heart of future deals. Otherwise, those with solely economic interests in our environment will only increase their wealth, as they have done between the 2009 Copenhagen summit and the 2015 Paris climate conference. The number of billionaires with interests in fossil fuel activities rose from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://oi-files-d8-prod.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/s3fs-public/file_attachments/mb-extreme-carbon-inequality-021215-en.pdf","children":[{"text":"54 in 2010 to 88 in 2015"}]},{"text":", expanding their collective riches by around 50% (from over $200 billion to more than $300 billion). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It’s clear that many of the biggest anti-climate forces won’t act without decisive government action and binding legislation. While there have been murmurs that Covid-19 has given our planet some much-needed respite, some opportunistic lobbying groups and corporations have chosen now as "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=ck8w5q10w004y07424aaatqxs","children":[{"text":"their time to covertly pounce"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This pandemic has revealed the speed in which governments are able put swift measures in place when faced with an emergency. Nevertheless, when Covid-19 is over, the same actions and level of attention need to be afforded to the climate crisis, if we are to slow its impact. It’s time to think seriously about levelling the playing field. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lucy Pearson is a graduate from the University of Birmingham (BA Political Science). She now works for Teach First, a charity working to end educational inequality. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/lucy__pearson","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: #PlasticFreePints
subtitle: Our editor-in-chief introduces Ours to Save’s first campaign, in collaboration with Ecodisco.
author: Florence Wildblood
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Welcome to the weekend, and welcome to #plasticfreepints. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-51506729","children":[{"text":"Monday"}]},{"text":", we’ll be able to meet with up to six people from different households in gardens and parks, provided we stay local and socially-distant.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And to coincide with this exciting development, pubs all across the UK are opening their doors for takeaway, most importantly takeaway pints – ready to quench the thirst of millions who are quite frankly done with bottled beverages. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But, unless we take a step back and think about how we want this to go, we risk doing a lot of damage to our environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By now, you’ve probably read plenty of hot takes on how the coronavirus has changed how we think about the climate crisis, and how it’s given planet earth a much-needed breather. (If you haven’t, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=ckas05ihl00030764zhgq0iy3","children":[{"text":"here’s a good one"}]},{"text":"). "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":" Go get your #plasticfreepints, take a picture and tag @ours.tosave and @ecodisco_ on Instagram for the whole world to see."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This will be a test of what we’ve learnt. Are we serious about bringing new and sustainable habits into this changed world of ours? About showing our corporations and governments that we’ve had enough of plastic? We’ve got to come out of this crisis ready to fight back against the next one. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So, we’re urging you to join us in bringing along your own vessel - pint glass, milk bottle, vase, pickle jar, whatever - when you pick up your pint from the pub. It doesn’t matter whether you’re sipping on cider or cranberry juice. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1590761877/spazatura_dzwugv.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Just because you can't see it, doesn't mean it's not there. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ours to Save have teamed up with "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ecodisco.uk/","children":[{"text":"Ecodisco"}]},{"text":", who started out last year as London’s first ever plastic-free party at Oval Space, and are now working towards securing the longevity of the nightlife industry in harmony with the natural world. Their founder Hadi Ahmazadeh was named one of London’s most influential figures in nightlife by the Evening Standard last year. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If (and only if!) you haven’t got a suitable vessel already, you’ll very soon be able to get your hands on an Ecodisco recycled stainless steel cup. The cups are made on demand so there won’t be any excess, and they’re shaping up to be pretty snazzy. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We’re also working alongside some pubs who are already doing great things for the environment. Think growlers, cocktails in glass bottles, and pint glasses at cost price. We’ll be profiling these in our Features section over the next few weeks, so you can pay them a visit if you’re nearby. You might even see #plasticfreepints cropping up on pub blackboards over the coming weeks (shoutout to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.thecrookedwell.com/","children":[{"text":"The Crooked Well"}]},{"text":" and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.thewheatsheafsw17.com/","children":[{"text":"The Wheatsheaf "}]},{"text":"in South London for their early support!). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So, all that’s left for you to do is go get your #plasticfreepints (while maintaining a distance from your pals), take a picture, and tag "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/ours.tosave/","children":[{"text":"@ourstosave"}]},{"text":" and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/ecodisco_/","children":[{"text":"@ecodisco_"}]},{"text":" on Instagram for the whole world to see! Eventually, we’ll pick a winner from all the images at random – and he or she will get a sizeable number of plastic-free pints on us. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Even if you don’t win, you’ll be helping spread the word about a very important cause. No one likes the taste of a pint from a plastic cup; no one likes overflowing dustbins in parks; and no one likes the excess resources, energy and waste that come with disposable cups.  "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1590762466/Screen_Shot_2020-05-29_at_15.24.22_j1yjfp.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This could be you! (Kind of). Image courtesy of Ecodisco. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If you want to know more","bold":true},{"text":" about the impact of single-use plastic, there’s a run-down "},{"type":"link","url":"https://plastic.education/the-problem-with-disposable-cups/","children":[{"text":"here"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Key takeaways: inputs for production draw on finite natural resources, the energy used to produce "},{"text":"billions","italic":true},{"text":" of cups per year increases greenhouse gas emissions, and less than 1% of plastic cups produced are recycled - destroying outdoors environments. ICYMI, the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.britannica.com/topic/Great-Pacific-Garbage-Patch","children":[{"text":"Great Pacific Garbage Patch "}]},{"text":"is similar in size to Afghanistan. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If you’re worried about hygiene","bold":true},{"text":", in light of Starbucks and others banning reusable cups, check out "},{"type":"link","url":"https://grist.org/climate/can-the-zero-waste-movement-survive-the-coronavirus/","children":[{"text":"this enlightening piece "}]},{"text":"from Grist, which essentially argues that the stereotypes of disposable cups as clean and reusable cups as unhygienic are both wrong. But obviously, stay safe out there and be sure to wash you cup between uses. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And if you’ve got any ideas","bold":true},{"text":", contributions or musings - or would like to get involved - just drop me a line on florence@ourstosave.com. title: "Our dollar is our best vote"
subtitle: When it comes to plastic pollution, Seaside Scavenge encourage behaviour change for system change.
author: Anna Turitsyna
bio: If this piece captures your attention, and you haven't already, be sure to take part in our #plasticfreepints campaign.
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.seasidescavenge.org/","children":[{"text":"Seaside Scavenge"}]},{"text":" was founded by AJ Linke in early 2015 as a small initiative focusing on combining beach clean-ups and clothes swaps. Since then, her project has spread internationally and has become a platform for educating communities on conscious consumerism and its potential for the planet. What part can the regular consumer play in shifting the practices of companies worldwide? I spoke to AJ in search of some answers. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The idea for Seaside Scavenge originated from AJ’s time abroad. “I was living in Chile for over a year when I first started to notice plastic pollution, and working in communities to draw attention to it.” She elaborates, “When I got back, I wanted to organise a beach clean-up and clothes swap event. I started to chat about it with friends and over a couple of months the idea developed that the litter collected could become the currency to buy the clothes.”"}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“You need to consider the size of the plastic, whether the type of plastic can be discerned and how dirty it is before you put it in a recycling bin. Recycling is not the golden child.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So, how do the scavenges work and what makes them unique? Participants collect litter and it is catalogued by volunteers for submission to the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.tangaroablue.org/","children":[{"text":"Australian Marine Debris Initiative (AMDI)"}]},{"text":" Database. The most common items found are cigarette butts, soft plastics (such as plastic bags), plastic straws, and takeaway food packaging, which correlate with "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.plasticfreejuly.org/what-others-do/how-lucie-said-goodbye-to-the-top-four-single-use-plastics/","children":[{"text":"the big four items the ‘Plastic Free July’ campaign recommends avoiding"}]},{"text":". For every ten pieces of litter participants gather, regardless of size, they receive a token. Tokens are used as ‘currency’ at the seaside markets set up by Seaside Scavenge, which consist of donations from the community. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the first clean-up she hosted in March 2015, AJ recalls, “I just wanted to engage members of the public who had never thought about marine plastic pollution or over-consumption, and introduce them to it in a chilled and fun environment.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The element of fun is certainly key to the scavenge experience and continues to this day. Entertainment from local musicians, workshops, marine talks, and competitions, including 'Most Ciggie Butts' picked up, are prominent features of the clean-ups. Best of all, participants get to walk away with pre-loved items and give them a second home, as ‘payment’ for their efforts. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1591113536/IMG_7354_peb9e3.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This exchange of ‘trash for treasure’ has proven extremely successful. As of May 2020, there have been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.seasidescavenge.org/our-impac","children":[{"text":"over 70 events hosted and 13,450 kg of litter picked up"}]},{"text":" from waterways around the globe by Seaside Scavenge. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, the wider issue at play here is the amount of litter generated in the first place. This needs to be addressed before this litter has a chance to filter into our waterways. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It is a problem that needs tackling from the root, as even items collected on the scavenges may not necessarily be recyclable by the time they are discovered. “Typically, people consider all plastic, all cardboard, all glass to be recyclable and this is the way we have been educated, but it’s not as straightforward as that.” AJ elaborates, “The challenge with broken up plastics that have been degraded by UV rays or salt is that you often can’t tell what the plastic type is. You need to consider the size of the plastic, whether the type of plastic can be discerned and how dirty it is before you put it in a recycling bin. Recycling is not the golden child.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Understanding that we must do more than simply recycle is key to the education Seaside Scavenge imparts at its events. The growing awareness of the impact of waste, and what we can do as consumers, is the new message they are spreading. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“When the organisation started, waste was not really high priority on people’s agendas. So, it was really about raising awareness. Now we are trying to shift that awareness to behaviour change. We are really encouraging participants to look at a circular economy and trying to break that down for people, as it is quite a new term and a lot of businesses are starting to adopt it. If people start to understand that waste is actually a resource and it’s not just a linear model where we throw it away – there is no away, it ends up in a hole or the ocean – we actually start to reframe the way we think about the products we’re buying and where they end up, once we no longer want them.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1591113778/IMG_7086_m8ojij.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Behaviour change is the next step after awareness. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/info/live-work-travel-eu/consumers/sustainable-consumption_en","children":[{"text":"Studies have found"}]},{"text":" people’s purchasing habits can shift towards longer-lasting products if they are provided with support and education. Changed habits grant consumers a power to dictate the direction of policy changes, which ensure harmful industries shift to sustainable practices, thus leading to system change."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Social media is a powerful tool when it comes to creating campaigns for system change. Australia saw overall plastic bag usage"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nra.net.au/media-release/1-5-billion-single-use-plastic-bags-eliminated-since-july/","children":[{"text":" drop by 80% "}]},{"text":"when a small fee was introduced to supermarkets, following pressure from campaigners.  McDonalds switched from plastic to paper straws in several countries in 2018 after "},{"type":"link","url":"https://actions.sumofus.org/a/mcdonalds-is-polluting-our-oceans","children":[{"text":"nearly half a million people"}]},{"text":" signed a petition demanding action. As of 2020,"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.containerdepositsystems.com.au/articles/container-deposit-schemes-globally","children":[{"text":" six Australian states have introduced a container deposit system"}]},{"text":", where residents can exchange their plastic bottles for ten cents each, as a result of the growing awareness of the plastic problem. Changing our behaviour as consumers might feel like a drop in the ocean, but evidence suggests it really does drive system change. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1591113947/5ddd8e_7a17e8e6d17841bab8a9bb374044f113_fg5vqh.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"AJ’s message is clear: “System change won’t happen without individual behaviour change and that’s why it’s so important. In this modern era, our dollar is our best vote. Over the last five years, plastic has become a huge issue globally but that’s not because McDonalds decided to create paper straws. It is because hundreds of thousands of people from all different countries have started to notice how much plastic is ending up in their communities and starting to activate around it. As a result, they become switched on and decide “I’m not going to buy this product. It goes against what I believe in.” We are the customer, the customer is typically always right, and that is how the system change eventually becomes.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Next time you are doing a weekly shop, take a moment to consider the actual power you have as a consumer. The issue is greater than your individual waste and as AJ expresses “I don’t think me making my yoghurt every week has an impact on the global collective waste, but it does on a bigger collective mindfulness and mission of shifting our global consumer behaviour, and that’s where we really need to focus our energy.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of Seaside Scavenge. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Anna Turitsyna is an Electrical and Electronic Engineering student at University College London. She is part of UCL Climate Action Society and volunteers her time with Generation Climate Europe. You can find her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/annaturitsyna","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]}]

title: Recycling, democratised
subtitle: Just 40% of waste in Lagos was collected when Wecyclers emerged in 2012. Here’s how the organisation is changing things.
author: Funmi Lijadu
bio: If this piece captures your attention, and you haven't already, be sure to take part in our #plasticfreepints campaign.
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many developing countries face a singular challenge when it comes to sustainability: how do you make environmentalism work within an ineffective system? One answer – through creativity. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"http://wecyclers.com/","children":[{"text":"Wecyclers"}]},{"text":", based in Lagos, Nigeria, is a creative initiative that encourages recycling in a country where its relevance is not always understood. When it first started in 2012, just 40% of the city’s waste was collected, and only 13% recycled. Waste was commonly burnt when not collected, leading to toxic air pollution in crowded neighbourhoods. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These problems continue, but Wecyclers is fighting back. It democratises recycling, making it available and attractive to the city's most vulnerable groups. Its model is aimed at low-income communities, with a points-based system that lets subscribers collect cash rewards for recycling. Many of Wecyclers’ clients live in informal, slum settlements where overcrowding is an inescapable reality; through a better waste collection system, spread of disease reduces and quality of life improves. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Much more needs to be done for waste in the sprawling metropolis to be handled sustainably. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Wecyclers have the capacity to recycle and reuse an extensive range of materials, maximising their contribution to litter reduction. The company collects glass, aluminium, paper, cardboard and varying types of plastic, including plastic bottles and their lids. In "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/p/B1jD1X9nbGs/?igshid=4q1b3mo71wnf","children":[{"text":"Obalende, Ikoyi"}]},{"text":" there is a Wecyclers Recycling Exchange centre where people can exchange their recyclables in person for cash rewards. Additionally, there is a waste collection hub in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/p/B0rIWo4lDnD/?igshid=gt7dz6vks30l","children":[{"text":"Ebutte Metta"}]},{"text":" on Lagos’ mainland. Collected materials are then processed in various centres in Lagos. In Nigeria, where products are often temporarily used and thrown away, Wecyclers’ management of plastic is an important short-term solution to the monumental problem of waste. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many of Lagos’ most impoverished citizens are still not using this service due to access and educational issues. Some will not have received a full formal education; reading and writing is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/NGA/nigeria/literacy-rate","children":[{"text":"not universal"}]},{"text":", and neither is knowledge on how waste leads to pollution. Nevertheless, the Wecyclers team continue to go into informal settlements to spread awareness about their services through word-of-mouth. The hope is that once people hear about the recycling initiative in person, awareness will spread organically. In this way, they will be able to contribute to sustainable waste management in a way that benefits and makes sense financially for them."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1591262050/89299465_2974361785984498_7896960039905132544_o_hzmjps.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The initiative is also a means for financially-empowered citizens to process their waste responsibly. Citizens are more inclined to use Wecyclers over other waste management organisations because it monetises waste so creatively and efficiently. Government agencies taking care of waste are often overwhelmed, so are not able to thoroughly collect waste in Lagos. Lagos Waste Management Authority (LAWMA) is the government’s agency in charge of waste management in the city, and has struggled to sustainably manage the city’s waste. Within Lagos, LAWMA landfills appear ineffectively managed, with the dumping of waste done in centres close to highways, exposing travellers to unpleasant smells and increasing their risk of developing respiratory diseases. Much more needs to be done for waste in the sprawling metropolis to be handled sustainably. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Wecyclers is a very positive start. It’s a free service, and is starting a ripple effect of awareness about waste in Nigeria. The big gaps in LAWMA’s sustainability render the work of Wecyclers crucial to effective waste management in Nigeria. Looking to the future, consumer habits must change so as to minimise the amount of rubbish produced in the first place, but LAWMA must also work on innovative solutions, as current management strategies like street sweepers and landfills are proving insufficient. Perhaps by learning from Wecyclers’ strategies, the government group could guarantee a more sustainable future for Lagos’ constantly growing population. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of Wecyclers.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://funmi-lijadu.squarespace.com/","children":[{"text":"Funmi Lijadu ","italic":true}]},{"text":"is a writer and collage artist highlighting the stories that are less told. She is invested in humanity, the histories that led to our present, and imagining better futures. ","italic":true}]}]

title: Powered by the sun
subtitle: Droughts have made Zambia's reliance on hydropower unsustainable. Now the country is embracing solar energy.
author: Derrick Silimina
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At first glance, all is well. Zambia’s immense water bodies are propelling major hydropower plants to meet the nation’s electricity needs in a clean and renewable way. For many years, the country's electrical energy has been generated thanks to water flows from the mighty Zambezi, Kafue, Luangwa, and Chambishi Rivers."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, the southern African country is now reconsidering its long-time dependence on hydropower, as chronic droughts cut production at its massive hydro dams. These droughts - caused by climate change - have in recent years lowered water levels, severely curtailing power production. Zambia has as a result seen electricity shortages estimated at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theigc.org/blog/lights-out-zambias-electricity-crisis/","children":[{"text":"around one third "}]},{"text":"of its total installed hydroelectric capacity. In 2019, water levels in the Kariba dam - one of the country’s key manmade dams - plunged to their lowest yet, falling to 10% of usable storage since 1996."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“This is probably the worst drought that has hit Zambia since independence in 1964,” Energy Minister Matthew Nkhuwa recently "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/zambias-dependence-hydropower-becoming-increasingly-problematic","children":[{"text":"told"}]},{"text":" parliament."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Chronic electricity shortages have affected everyone, from individuals to small businesses and huge corporations."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In addition to unpredictable weather patterns, a lack of investment in hydro projects has also caused complications. Even if rain does fall, power supply simply cannot keep up with demand from the mining, manufacturing and agriculture sectors."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Zambia’s over-dependence on hydropower is unsustainable. Energy experts have argued that as droughts lead to prolonged blackouts, the country ought to be developing other renewable fuel sources, such as solar and wind energy."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1591709635/batokagorge_uwzhlc.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Zambezi River. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In an effort to diversify its energy sources, Zambia is entering agreements with corporations looking to invest in its energy sector. Recently, the country signed an agreement with the IFC to develop two large-scale solar projects. Only a few weeks ago, Zambia’s state-owned electricity provider "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.reuters.com/article/zambia-electricity-idUSL8N2D31ZJ","children":[{"text":"signed a contract"}]},{"text":" with Power China to develop three solar power plants to feed into its national grid."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Less attention has been paid to wind energy, but several promising projects are underway. Construction of a 200MW wind power project in Katete, Eastern Province is expected to start in 2021. This is the first phase of the larger Unika 1 wind project, and will be financed by private investors."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These impending improvements are good news for Zambia’s citizens. Chronic electricity shortages have affected everyone, from individuals to small businesses and huge corporations."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“These projects are badly needed and long overdue. Look! For me to make it in this sector, I need electricity to refrigerate my milk products and the rolling power blackouts have wrecked Zambia’s already fragile economy,” says Pamela Kabwe, a dairy farmer based in the Chisamba area."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"The hope is that solar energy will contribute not just to a climate-resilient Zambia, but to a low-carbon continent. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“My business is down due to lack of electricity,” says Christine Chembe, the operator of a hair salon in the capital city of Lusaka. “The government should prepare adequately to invest in other renewable energies instead of always depending on hydropower from the Kariba dam, year in and year out.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Local markets, shops and chain stores are flooded with various solar appliances – from water pumps and radio sets to phone chargers and lights – as people try to take the problem of blackouts into their own hands. For David Chibuye, an entrepreneur at Kamwala market in Lusaka, business is booming. Ever since the power blackouts started, he tells me, he has been selling more solar-powered equipment. “I never used to have clients like these days. Nowadays, demand for solar-related products has gone up here and, given more capital, I will make more money.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But this is just the beginning. Zambia has an average of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.lusakatimes.com/2017/02/13/sola-kiosk-innovation-brings-extra-cold-refreshments-rural-areas/","children":[{"text":"2,000-3,000 hours"}]},{"text":" of sunshine per year, waiting to be turned into energy. The International Renewable Energy Agency "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.afdb.org/en/news-and-events/why-africa-is-the-next-renewables-powerhouse-18822","children":[{"text":"estimates"}]},{"text":" that renewable energy capacity in Africa could reach 310GW by 2030, putting the continent at the forefront of renewable energy generation globally. When its larger solar energy projects are finished, both Zambia's natural environment and its  citizens will benefit hugely. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1591710605/139411201033386847077304_cwll9l.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Solar power looks set to be the answer.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As it stands, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.usaid.gov/powerafrica/zambia","children":[{"text":"only 4%"}]},{"text":" of Zambia’s rural population has access to electricity.
