title: Plastic is a party problem
subtitle: Meet the clubs and pubs on the frontline of the fight against plastic.
author: Jack McGovan
bio: If this piece captures your attention, and you haven't already, be sure to take part in our #plasticfreepints campaign.
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sustainability, and the impact humans are having on the planet, is complex; it can’t be reduced to carbon emissions and air pollution, as it often was at the height of coronavirus lockdown. Since the days where people were scouring the shelves for the last bottle of sanitiser, or hopelessly hunting for even a square of toilet roll in an effort to save their old socks, our levels of waste have increased. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/09/us-coronavirus-outbreak-agriculture-food-supply-waste","children":[{"text":"Food was left to rot "}]},{"text":"in the fields. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/26/21194647/the-covid-19-pandemic-is-generating-tons-of-medical-waste","children":[{"text":"Medical waste piled up "}]},{"text":"while frontline workers battled the pandemic. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://theconversation.com/using-lots-of-plastic-packaging-during-the-coronavirus-crisis-youre-not-alone-135553","children":[{"text":"Plastic lined our cupboards "}]},{"text":"as we stocked up on supplies."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Restrictions around the world are slowly being eased and we have to be careful not to bring this extra waste with us in our return to partial normality. Pick-up-pints might offer a ray of hope to those in the UK suffering a publess existence, but the resulting overuse of plastic cups is exacerbating a problem that lockdown has already intensified. Nonetheless, plastic has been a party problem for a long time, though the baggy-ridden toilet floors are only a scratch on the reflective surface."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Plastic waste is a big problem in clubs","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" During the pinnacle of my rebellious phase in my late teens, I spent a few years working in nightclubs across Newcastle in lieu of pursuing my degree. Here, I saw firsthand the sheer scale of plastic waste generated by clubs on a nightly basis. But just how much plastic do we sacrifice on the altar of having a good time?"}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“If clubbers refuse single-use items, or if they actively ask for reusable items, this can already be a huge help — some clubs think their guests wouldn’t support moves to make their venues more sustainable.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It’s hard to say,” says Konstanze Meyer, the Project Manager of "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.clubliebe-festival.org/","children":[{"text":"Clubliebe"}]},{"text":", a Berlin-based organisation dedicated to creating a sustainable club culture. “The clubs themselves probably don’t know, as not all of them even separate their waste. It’s also hard to guess because there are so many variables, like whether they use plastic straws, cups, shot glasses, or sell drinks in plastic bottles.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Some attempts to reduce plastic waste in the scene have been made. For example, DJ Ante Perry organised a no-plastic disco, where single-use plastics were replaced with cornstarch alternatives. “At Clubliebe, our main focus is on carbon footprint reduction, but we always consult with clubs and try to help them to reduce their waste, with an emphasis on reusing items”, she says. In addition to using reusable cups and straws, she suggested that clubs could make their own DIY cleaning products, instead of buying those packaged in plastic."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592043127/016A7840_y0pvsi.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A zero-waste workshop at Clubliebe. Image courtesy of Karoline Kohle/clubliebe e.V.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Although the clubs hold most of the responsibility, there is still a lot clubbers can do to help reduce waste”, she tells me, “If clubbers refuse single-use items, or if they actively ask for reusable items, this can already be a huge help — some clubs think their guests wouldn’t support moves to make their venues more sustainable.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another huge problem – one Konstanze feels needs to be discussed more – is that clubbers leave their waste in the streets surrounding the venues. With hundreds, even thousands, of people descending on a club in one particular night, you can imagine the amount of waste left lying around in the neighbourhood – as well as the impact this has on the environment."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Konstanze also informs me that there are more creative ways to get involved, “We’re currently running a "}, {"type": "link", "url": "http://clubtopia.de/blogbeitrag/future-party-idea-contest/", "children":[{"text": "competition"}]}, {"text": " till the end of August to collect ideas on how to make club culture more sustainable — all ideas [including those not about plastic] are welcome, as are people from all over the world!”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There are precedents for moving away from single-use plastics","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"When it comes to the topic of single-use plastics, a few success stories shine through from back home in the UK. Liverpool-based Meraki "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.residentadvisor.net/news/71484","children":[{"text":"announced last year"}]},{"text":" that they would be going ‘99 percent single-use plastic-free’ by implementing a system using reusable cups, while also replacing bottled water with cans. Aluminium cans "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theverge.com/2019/9/12/20862775/aluminum-recycling-water-tech-plastic-manufacturing-cocacola-pepsi-apple","children":[{"text":"are more easily recycled"}]},{"text":", but they still "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.forbes.com/sites/woodmackenzie/2019/09/02/will-aluminium-cans-replace-plastic-bottles/","children":[{"text":"require a large amount of energy to produce"}]},{"text":", meaning it’s always better to stick to tap water if it’s an option. Other venues which have made changes include Oval Space and The Pickle Factory - who have swapped single-use plastics for cornstarch alternatives. Camden Town Brewery also went into partnership with Arsenal to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.arsenal.com/news/re-usable-cups-camden-town-brewery","children":[{"text":"implement a reusable cup scheme "}]},{"text":"for the 19/20 season. Elsewhere in the world, DC10 in Ibiza "},{"type":"link","url":"https://djmag.com/news/dc-10-ibiza-has-banned-single-use-plastics","children":[{"text":"announced in May last year"}]},{"text":" that they would be banning single-use plastics from their club."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592043511/79994330_2413400955437707_5254460138068115456_o_lq8yu5.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Reusable cups at Meraki. Image courtesy of Meraki. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We see that reusable cup schemes can actually be quite successful”, says Hadi Ahmadzadeh, the founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ecodisco.uk/","children":[{"text":"ECODISCO."}]},{"text":" “When buying their first drink, customers put a pound deposit down to use the cup for the evening. For the next drink, they’re able to reuse the cup or swap it for a clean one” he continues.“The best way for clubs to succeed is to invest in the right infrastructure by ensuring they have suitable storage space and washing facilities — from what we’ve seen, it takes about two years to make the money back”. One of the benefits of such a system is that conscious clubbers end up subsidising it by taking their cup home to use elsewhere, though there are also those who forget to reclaim their deposit in their race to the nearest takeaway, “The kickback from this actually helps venues to make a return on their investment a lot faster”."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With ECODISCO, it’s Hadi’s aim to eradicate single-use plastics from clubs. The long term plan is to offer a pick up, drop off and cleaning service for reusable cups on a contractual basis. Obviously, they’ll be using electric vehicles to do so. “It can be hard to convince club owners to get on board, so we want to make it as easy as possible for them”, Hadi explains, “Proper storage space and washing facilities can be logistically difficult, and this is the gap that we hope to fill”."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The reason that they advocate for reusables and not compostable alternatives is that mass consumption of any product still has a detrimental impact on the environment. In addition, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20191030-why-biodegradables-wont-solve-the-plastic-crisis","children":[{"text":"compostable often means it can only be done industrially"}]},{"text":", with many of these products simply "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-47238220","children":[{"text":"ending up in landfills"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"If we come out of the other side of lockdown and resume business as usual, we can expect to have more plastic than fish"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.businessinsider.com/plastic-in-ocean-outweighs-fish-evidence-report-2017-1?r=DE&IR=T","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":" in the ocean by weight as soon as 2050. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“So far, we’ve only really had positive feedback”, George Griffin – director of Meraki – tells me. “A few people moan about having to put a deposit down, but once we explain the concept, they’re usually ok with it.” Having made the change to reusable cups around six months ago, they’ve already made back about 50% of their initial investment. “At the end of the day, these changes are going to come eventually, so we thought it best to just jump the gun — it’s actually a lot easier to do than people think it is.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592043595/729B6191_1_ebmuog.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Recycled steel cups at an ECODISCO event. Image courtesy of ECODISCO. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Social restrictions offer us time for reflection","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Perhaps where there has been more widespread success is the reduction in the use of plastic straws, with c"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/2018/07/news-plastic-drinking-straw-history-ban/","children":[{"text":"ertain cities implementing blanket bans"}]},{"text":". Over the last few years, these small, hollow cylinders have been continually vilified, most likely due to the viral videos showing turtles and other marine animals impaled by them, having almost lost their lives to a product of fleeting value. Although there are situations where plastic straws remain necessary — for example, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/aug/25/plastic-straw-ban-california-people-with-disabilities","children":[{"text":"for people with disabilities"}]},{"text":" — the bans show that we can outlaw products we once saw as useful when it becomes socially acceptable to do so."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The sad truth is that none of us will be going to a party any time soon, but this downtime gives us a chance to reflect on both our collective and individual behaviours. If we come out of the other side of lockdown and resume business as usual, we can expect to have "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.businessinsider.com/plastic-in-ocean-outweighs-fish-evidence-report-2017-1?r=DE&IR=T","children":[{"text":"more plastic than fish"}]},{"text":" in the ocean by weight as soon as 2050. The experts say that the best thing to do is to make your favourite venues aware that you want change, while also being mindful of how you consume plastic in the hours leading up to front of the queue. It might take a lot of work to reduce plastic use in light of the pandemic, but it’s better for morale if we take the cup-half-full approach. Let’s just make sure the cup is reusable. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jack McGovan is a freelance writer who likes to tackle topics related to creating a fairer and more sustainable world. In particular, he enjoys examining how sustainability intersects with modern culture and science, using his background in chemistry as a tool to help communicate technical concepts to a wider audience.","italic":true}]}]

title: Saving Seagrass
subtitle: Can we combat the silent loss of our underwater meadows?
author: Esmé Audland
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On a global scale, the equivalent of two football fields of seagrass - an integral marine habitat - are lost every single hour. To date, 92% of the UK’s seagrass population has disappeared. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Poor water quality, primarily driven by excess nutrients, is one of the largest threats faced by seagrass both in the UK and globally.  At this point there is, sadly, little evidence of our diminished seagrass population recovering naturally. Although there have only been a few restoration projects across the UK thus far, conservation efforts have been increasing rapidly over the last few decades. The charity "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.projectseagrass.org/","children":[{"text":"Project Seagrass"}]},{"text":" is at the forefront of these efforts, experimenting in the replantation of the UK’s underwater meadows. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Seagrass meadows are able to sequester and store carbon 40 times faster than tropical forests."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Under the Paris Climate Accord, seagrass restoration can be part of defined emissions reduction targets and traded for carbon credits. Moreover, through the lens of ‘rewilding’ on land and under the sea, seagrass conservation and restoration has garnered an increasing amount of interest. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The importance of seagrass meadows is, however, continually overlooked in the fight against climate change. Mainstream media tend to focus heavily on damage to coral reefs and rainforests when, in fact, seagrass meadows are able to sequester and store carbon 40 times faster than tropical forests. In so doing, they maintain a water pH that protects animals with external skeletons such as corals and molluscs from the damage caused by ocean acidification. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Found in shallow soft sediment or subtidal areas, and covering up to 600,000km² of our shallow oceans, seagrass provides food and shelter to thousands of species. From juvenile fish such as Atlantic cod (the world’s third most caught species of fish) to endangered seahorses and manatees, the nurseries found in our underwater meadows are critical to the survival of marine ecosystems all over the world. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As part of a group of plants called monocotyledons, the long leaves of seagrasses also work to absorb energy from waves hitting the coast. The roots anchor underwater sediment and prevent coastal erosion, further protecting our coastlines from the increasingly prevalent threat of storms and rising tides. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592425250/IMGP0063_onosar.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Save Our Seahorses.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Coastal fishing areas provide an income to over one billion people worldwide. Seagrass meadows support one fifth of the world’s largest fisheries, so the economic repercussions of a decline in these species will be catastrophic. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Based in Cardiff, Project Seagrass engages in direct action as well as researching the structure, function and resilience of seagrass meadows. Describing their approach with the simple phrase ‘underwater gardening’, the team at Project Seagrass work to collect, separate and plant seagrass seeds. Seeds are collected each summer by staff, students and volunteers across the UK, before being transported to a laboratory at Swansea University. Here, they are processed and packaged in hessian bags with sediment, ready to be deployed at potential restoration sites. Hessian is commonly used to control erosion on steep slopes and wrap exposed roots of trees and shrubs during transportation, so is an optimal material for the project. In addition, because they’re made from natural vegetable fibres, the hessian bags used by Project Seagrass are completely biodegradable. They cause no harm or pollution to the environment the team are trying to protect. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So far, 94% of bags have successfully developed mature seagrass roots. Moving forward, sites where germination has failed will be replaced with more optimal environments. Despite some failures, the Bags of Seagrass Seeds Line (BoSSLine) method proves the efficiency of conservation and restoration measures that take direct action. While a laboratory is required for processing, beyond the initial collection of seeds, very little diver-based work is needed, thus reducing costs and skills required to carry out the project. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Project Seagrass’s method is simple and effective. By the sound of it, we can look forward to the further restoration of our underwater meadows. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Click ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fevo.2019.00311/full","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":" for a more in depth study of Project Seagrass’s methodology. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Esmé Audland is an English student at UCL. Passionate about environmental sustainability and plant-based eating, she works in marketing for the new vegan restaurant directory ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sayplants.com/","children":[{"text":"SayPlants! ","italic":true}]},{"text":"and promotes delicious, low-impact cuisine at ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://deliciouslyella.com/","children":[{"text":"Deliciously Ella","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: What has the Green New Deal got to do with colonialism?
subtitle: We need to make sure this potentially groundbreaking resolution doesn't impact negatively on the Global South.
author: Joycelyn Longdon
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Introduced to Congress in July 2019 by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York and Senator Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts, the Green New Deal is a congressional resolution that lays out a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/21/climate/green-new-deal-questions-answers.html","children":[{"text":"grand plan for tackling climate change"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Its 14 pages summarise the ways in which humans have affected and changed the planet’s climate and the steps governments, namely the US government, need to take to create legislation that allows us to tackle climate change in a way that benefits everyone. Other Western and developed powers, such as Europe, Japan and South Korea, are slowly creating their own versions of the Green New Deal too. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Human activity has been the dominant cause of observed climate change over the past century and the USA has contributed disproportionately to the climate crisis, producing 20% of global emissions. Because of this, the nation will need to take a leading role in reducing emissions. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We have been warned that global warming "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/sites/2/2019/06/SR15_Full_Report_High_Res.pdf","children":[{"text":"at or above 2 degrees celsius beyond pre-industrialisation levels "}]},{"text":"will cause a plethora of social, economic and environmental problems. There will be mass migration from the regions most affected by climate change, mainly in the Global South; there will be wildfires that by 2050 will annually destroy at least twice as much forest area in the western US as was typically burned by wildfires in preceding years; and we will lose 90% of coral reefs across the world. These impacts will damage around $1 trillion worth of public infrastructure and coastal real-estate in the USA. They will also lead to a loss of $500 billion in the country’s annual economic output. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592512172/2092x1396px_Volunteers-and-Fire-Rescue-officers-fight-a-bushfire_htuetz.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ipcc.ch/","children":[{"text":"IPCC"}]},{"text":" has also reported that, in order to keep global temperatures at a stable level, we will need global reductions in greenhouse emissions from human sources of 40-60% from 2010 levels by 2030. We will then have to reach net-zero emissions by 2050."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Things need to change, and they need to change soon."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With a Green New Deal, we may well be able to deliver this change – all the while concentrating on the areas where we’re currently failing when it comes to the intersection of climate and social justice. Climate change, pollution and environmental destruction have exacerbated the systematic racial, regional, social, environmental and economic injustices "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.congress.gov/116/bills/hres109/BILLS-116hres109ih.pdf","children":[{"text":"faced by "}]},{"text":"frontline and vulnerable communities.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These communities include indigenous communities, communities of colour, migrant communities, deindustrialised communities, depopulated rural communities, the poor, low-income workers, women, the elderly, the unhoused, people with disabilities, and youth. The Green New Deal hopes to create a framework in which these systemic injustices can be counteracted. Its aim is to tackle inequity and climate change simultaneously, ensuring that all of the aforementioned groups benefit from green solutions. These people, after all, are more likely to suffer the effects of climate change first-hand. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, there are fears that the Green New Deal could exacerbate what scholars like "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.libarts.colostate.edu/people/drdoreen/","children":[{"text":"Doreen Martinez"}]},{"text":" call "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.doi.org/10.5749/wicazosareview.29.2.0063","children":[{"text":"climate colonialism "}]},{"text":"— the domination of less powerful countries and peoples through initiatives meant to slow the pace of global warming. There’s a chance that these countries will suffer as others ‘offset’ the effects of their emissions-producing activity."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For instance, The Oakland Institute has "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.oaklandinstitute.org/sites/oaklandinstitute.org/files/Report_DarkerSideofGreen_hirez.pdf","children":[{"text":"reported"}]},{"text":" on the effect of carbon offsetting by several Norway-based companies. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://psmag.com/social-justice/how-the-gnd-can-avoid-climate-colonialism","children":[{"text":"Carbon offsets are a form of investment"}]},{"text":" in greenhouse gas emissions reduction that lets the buyer ‘offset’ the effects of their emissions-producing activity. The Norwegian companies bought and ‘conserved’ forest land in East Africa, but this came at the cost of forced evictions and food scarcity for thousands of Ugandans, Mozambicans, and Tanzanians. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592513147/ricepadis_smw5i1.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carbon offsetting often creates more problems than it solves.  ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another way colonial tendencies could appear in the Green New Deal is through the rush to meet renewable energy demand. Africa’s power generating capacity has "},{"type":"link","url":"https://qz.com/africa/1084847/sub-saharan-africa-is-still-in-the-dark-but-north-africa-will-soon-be-selling-power-to-europe/","children":[{"text":"slowly improved "}]},{"text":"over the years, but rationing, rolling shortages, and blackouts continue to hinder many countries' development — "},{"type":"link","url":"https://qz.com/411384/nigeria-is-shutting-down-for-business-thanks-to-its-worst-ever-fuel-shortages/","children":[{"text":"including economic giants"}]},{"text":" like South Africa and Nigeria. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While Sub-Saharan Africa stays largely in the dark, the power of the sun in North Africa is being harnessed, with billions being invested into large solar plants. Once operational, projects like the TuNur solar project in Tunisia, will open a new, "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.nurenergie.com/tunur/index.php/english/project/overview","children":[{"text":"intercontinental energy corridor"}]},{"text":" between North Africa and Europe. They will be delivering power to homes in Italy and France. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is an incredible technological advancement. But we should be asking questions about Africa providing the Global North with the energy it needs to facilitate further consumption, before meeting the basic energy, efficiency and stability demands of its own citizens."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The issues outlined above suggest a kind of ‘lifeboat ethics’, where we in the Global North use temporary sustainability to save ourselves – at the cost of the poor. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"It is important to note that the Green New Deal itself does not incite colonialism. Far from it. It is that the changes it calls for could lay the foundations (or act as an excuse for) for colonial agendas and behaviours."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, there is a more insidious threat to consider. One aspect of the ‘renewable industry’ that is often glazed over is the sourcing (mining) of materials. To build the machinery, factories, power stations and technology that produce renewable energy, we need materials like cobalt, lithium, silver and copper. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/green-new-deal-alexandria-ocasio-cortez-corbyn-colonialism-climate-change-a8899876.html","children":[{"text":"Behind each tonne extracted is a story"}]},{"text":" of water contamination and depletion, habitat destruction, deforestation, land poisoning, health impact and environmental conflict – primarily for those in the Global South. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Take cobalt, for example, which is used in rechargeable batteries. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/green-new-deal-alexandria-ocasio-cortez-corbyn-colonialism-climate-change-a8899876.html","children":[{"text":"58% is mined in the DRC"}]},{"text":". Its mining has contributed to a conflict that has blighted innumerable lives, caused air, water and soil contamination, and left the mining area as one of the top ten most polluted places in the world. With global demand for cobalt set to increase by as much as 423% by 2050, the future of those in the DRC, including child labourers, looks increasingly bleak. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These are only a few ways in which what some might call ‘sustainability’ can contribute to climate colonialism, and there are many more. But there is also definitely hope. It is important to note that the Green New Deal itself does not incite colonialism. Far from it. It is that the changes it calls for could lay the foundations (or act as an excuse for) for colonial agendas and behaviours. The Green New Deal has the potential to be an instrumental tool in our green transition. The politicians, human rights activists and conscious scientists, academics and legislators behind it can and should ensure that policies put in place to transition the West to a more sustainable infrastructure also provide a brighter future for everyone on Earth. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Joycelyn Longdon is a soon-to-be Climate Researcher embarking on a 4-year MRes + PhD at Cambridge University. She studies the application of artificial intelligence to climate change, and has a particular interest in empowering and supporting indigenous and ‘developing’ communities. She founded ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/climateincolour/","children":[{"text":"Climate In Colour","italic":true}]},{"text":" on Instagram as a space to document her journey and to make conversations around climate change more inclusive, accessible and interesting. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592511689/Screen_Shot_2020-06-18_at_21.21.10_tufwz0.png","children":[{"text":""}]}]

title: Designing for a Circular Economy
subtitle: More than 50,000 buildings are demolished every year. What happens next?
author: Florence Wildblood
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We’ve all seen buildings smashed to pieces behind billboards promising blue skies and state-of-the-art apartments. We’ve seen once-towering conglomerates of glass, metal and stone become pits of rubble by the side of the road. Buildings are built; we sleep, work and play in them; they get old or fall out of use and get demolished; new buildings are built. Unfortunately, there are some hefty gaps in this architectural circle of life. To patch them up, we need to ask where construction debris goes next – and to apply principles of reuse, rather than production, to the built environment."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Of the 200 million tonnes of waste generated in Britain annually, 63% is - according to Defra - construction debris. We lose tens of thousands of buildings to demolition each year and, to quote "},{"text":"The Architect’s Journal","italic":true},{"text":", ‘while more than 90% of the resulting waste material is recovered, much of this is recycled into a less valuable product or material, rather than being reused.’ Due to the sheer scale of building waste and the corporations that emit it, the difference between ‘downcycling’ and reuse is actually huge.   "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The construction industry is an insatiable consumer. Like other goods-based industries, it operates in line with a linear economic model – ‘take-make-use-waste’. Every building has something like the supply chain we more generally associate with supermarkets and clothes shops. And as it stands, each step in this chain entails its own negative environmental effects. At the start, when building materials are sourced, we see resource depletion, deforestation, and loss of biodiversity. At the end – wherever disused and demolished buildings end up – we see pollution of land, rivers and oceans."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Architects, designers and construction professionals should see the materials they use as part of a wider store of resources, rather than as one-off constituents of one-off projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It might seem counterintuitive, but we can learn a lot about how to fix this by looking to the past. We should be refurbishing and repurposing our buildings rather than knocking them down, and putting their core materials to good use if we do end up going forward with demolition. Working with reclaimed buildings and materials is a centuries-old practice; exemplary methods of building deconstruction and reuse crop up all throughout history. Before the Industrial Revolution – which brought mass production and machines to efficiently dispose of our waste – things were a little different."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Circumstances may have changed, but a new generation of architects and designers are preparing to embrace pre-industrial principles as they look towards a climate-conscious future. Charlotte Perkins – who decided to forge her own path after struggling to reconcile her environmentalism with her career choice – is one of them. I spoke to Charlotte about how architects, designers and construction companies can best face up to the realities of the linear economic model, and about her new venture, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.anotherworks.co.uk/","children":[{"text":"another"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592991958/491290_ba093f96_f3f0nl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Demolition of flats in Croxteth, Liverpool. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Architects and designers might seem a million miles away from the tonnes of waste at the other end of a building’s life cycle, but according to Charlotte, they “play a huge part in controlling the materials that are consumed”. The more architects and designers express an appetite to work with reclaimed materials, the “more support and investment there will be in the reuse market”. “If salvage companies are unable to sell materials and elements, they are unlikely to buy them from demolition contractors”."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This appetite isn’t yet revealing itself on a big enough scale. There a lot of hurdles, many of which Charlotte experienced first-hand while in practice. “Short-term profit-motivated budgets, clients’ and design teams’ negative perception of reclaimed materials, and the difficulty of buying in bulk on the second-hand market” all stand in the way of a more sustainable architecture."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“"},{"text":"The Architects Journal ","italic":true},{"text":"are currently running a campaign called "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/news/introducing-retrofirst-a-new-aj-campaign-championing-reuse-in-the-built-environment/10044359.article?blocktitle=intro&contentID=24810","children":[{"text":"Retrofirst"}]},{"text":", and one of their demands relates to VAT. We pay 20% VAT on most forms of refurbishment and renovation and typically between 0 and 5% on embodied carbon-heavy new builds. This incentivises rebuilding as opposed to renovation”, Charlotte tells me. “From a developer’s perspective it is much faster and cheaper to demolish and crush a building and where possible feed into recycling streams, than it is to carefully dismantle a building and its components keeping materials in a state for in situ reuse or sale elsewhere.” The result: materials are devalued, often crushed to produce hard core."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But building techniques can, and indeed must, change. Charlotte cites digital material passports, “a method of tracking a material’s life and use, which will help with issues related to structural performance”, and spaces dedicated to storing materials in anticipation of reuse, as developments to look out for."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In terms of change-making enterprises, we can look to Belgium-based "},{"type":"link","url":"http://rotordb.org/en","children":[{"text":"Rotor"}]},{"text":", who have “their own deconstruction and salvage company, as well as a design studio” and Feilden Fowles who designed London’s "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.feildenfowles.co.uk/waterloo-city-farm/","children":[{"text":"Waterloo City Farm"}]},{"text":" for disassembly. Just the other day, the BBC reported on"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feed","children":[{"text":" a first for Australian architecture"}]},{"text":": two skyscrapers that, instead of being knocked down in lieu of one bigger building, were stitched into one. 11,000 tonnes of carbon have been saved, say the architects. Thanks to government stimulus for green projects, a lot of money has been saved too."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592992376/Screen_Shot_2020-06-24_at_10.52.25_tsn88u.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Waterloo City Farm. Image courtesy of Feilden Fowles. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Now to another, Charlotte’s own smaller-scale project, where she’s fusing her expertise in architecture and interiors in a new and eco-conscious way. One pioneering design company might feel like a drop in the ocean up against the tonnes of construction debris we need to sift through, but another sets an example to be followed."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I wanted to work at a scale where I could stay true to my values”, says Charlotte, “I believe that influencing an industry that you know and understand from the inside to become more environmentally responsible can be as effective as being a front line activist - although this is important too!”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"another is a design company centred on the principle of reuse. “Wherever possible projects work with reclaimed buildings, elements and materials, and where this is not possible we design with a circular economy in mind. The aim of another is to inspire positive change, to help create an environmentally conscious and responsible construction industry.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A recent project provides a great example of how another’s principles work in action. Charlotte was recently commissioned to make a bathroom vanity unit, using a specific piece of reclaimed slate. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1592992470/IMG_0078_y5yfli.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"another's vanity unit.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In order to work with the slate’s size and uneven nature, a bespoke base was needed. “A big part of designing in the way we do is acknowledging that some reclaimed materials will require bespoke elements to incorporate them into projects”, says Charlotte."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Even though the oak used was new, Charlotte ensured it was responsibly sourced (FSC certified, European, and “cut to size to avoid unnecessary waste) and the vanity unit was designed with an afterlife in mind. “The unit was assembled using screws to allow for future disassembly, repair and reuse.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Clearly, decisions made at the very beginning of the design process set the scene for what happens at the end of a structure’s life cycle – whether it be a bathroom vanity unit or a skyscraper. Architects, designers and construction professionals should see the materials they use as part of a wider store of resources, rather than as one-off constituents of one-off projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"What does the circular economy mean to you?\", I ask Charlotte."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“In the context of another it means avoiding waste and understanding that everything created comes with an impact. It means working in a way that considers the before and after life of materials and spaces, avoiding unnecessary demolition and prioritising retention, reuse, and deconstruction instead.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Follow another on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/another_works/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: Are trees better than people?
subtitle: A conversation with Britain’s leading urban forester about street trees and green equity.
author: Alex Diggins
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John Parker is keen not to come across as “too much of a tree hugger”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nonetheless he says: “When you’re in front of a 2000-year-old Yew tree, it’s like nothing else. It’s the equivalent of standing beside the ocean, or looking up at a mountain – except, for most people, a tree is a just short stroll from your front door.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John has had more chances than most to get up close and personal with trees. He recently took up a senior role at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.trees.org.uk/","children":[{"text":"the Arboricultural Association"}]},{"text":", a charity and member organisation which represents people working with trees. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But before that he spent ten years with Transport for London (TfL) looking after the city’s more than 24,000 street trees – many of which line ‘red routes’, the capital’s busiest arterial roads. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593256545/JohnParker_miesxi.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John Parker, Senior Technical Officer at the Arboricultural Association. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Despite the thousands of trees in their care, TfL’s tree team is small and closely knit – only three people in an organisation of more than 20,000 employees who usually work to ensure the city’s Tube and bus network runs on time.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It was quite niche,” John admits. But working alongside the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ltoa.org.uk/","children":[{"text":"London Tree Officers Association "}]},{"text":"– who represent the city’s arboricultural workers – “a real sense of community” was built. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Though John is now well-known as an advocate for urban forests – his TED talk, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sYzaDCZHvR8&feature=emb_title","children":[{"text":"‘Why Trees Are Better Than People’"}]},{"text":", has been viewed nearly 4,000 times, and he has a lively following on "},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/johntree1981","children":[{"text":"Twitter"}]},{"text":" – his journey into arboriculture wasn’t straightforward.   "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"He started a law degree at Cardiff University, but dropped out to manage pubs. It was the suggestion of a friend, though, that led him to taking a diploma in arboriculture – and his job at TfL. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"\"There’s been a whole chain of people who’ve looked after those trees since the mid-1800s. We’ll never know their names – but there’s a sense of being part of something larger.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I was slightly feral as a child, always hanging around in the woods,” he says. “But I never realised it was possible to make a career out of trees until my mid-20s. It’s something we’re trying to address as an industry now – making young people realise they can make good money from climbing trees and hanging around in parks.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Urban trees are far from “ornamental”, though. In fact, they bring innumerable benefits to cities. A dense tree canopy provides an ‘urban cooling’ effect, helping to reduce the intense heat trapped by concrete and glass cityscapes; and trees filter the air, mitigating pollution. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But perhaps most remarkably, well-maintained street trees have been proven to foster “a sense of community”. This communal spirit drives down deprivation and petty crime which, in turn, makes the area a more pleasant place to live. It’s a virtuous cycle sometimes referred to as the ‘broken windows’ theory. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But John cautions: “We need to look more closely at who is receiving the benefits trees bring. Are they distributed evenly throughout society?” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Covid-19 pandemic has undoubtedly shown the advantages of living in close proximity to green space. But equally evident is the fact that those advantages are not inclusive and accessible to all. They can be gradated depressingly easily on the grounds of class, ethnicity and economic outcome."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Tackling this green inequality will be crucial to ensuring the UK’s arboricultural industry continues to thrive, John believes. But it will also be vital to combatting larger, systemic problems like the climate crisis. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593256545/738af578-5cac-4179-bb40-82a7a534a9b2_crbix8.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"John in action at the Stonehouse Community Climate Action Forum Day at the end of last year. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We’ve got a fantastic industry of diverse people passionate about trees. And I think it’s incredibly inspiring to see the work of a younger generation, and I hope their enthusiasm filters through. But we need more outreach – let kids know it’s a viable career.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“There’s a real disconnect between people and nature.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Despite these challenges, John is hopeful the sublime magic of urban trees will continue to grip imaginations – as they have his. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"He remembers caring for the plane trees on London’s Embankment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Tree officers are the custodians. There’s been a whole chain of people who’ve looked after those trees since the mid-1800s. We’ll never know their names – but there’s a sense of being part of something larger. And that’s a wonderful privilege.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Arboricultural Association has a selection of free ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://trees.org.uk/Training-Events/Online-Learning","children":[{"text":"online learning resources","italic":true}]},{"text":", and regularly broadcasts talks and lectures from leading tree experts. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Alex Diggins is a writer and critic based in London. He contributes regularly to The Economist, The Times Literary Supplement and The Spectator, and is currently working on a book about holy islands and the climate crisis. Follow him on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/AHABDiggins","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: Renewable energy: the hidden human cost
subtitle: Without respect for human rights, the clean energy industry risks the entire fight to avert the climate crisis.
author: Harriet Wood
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We have known for years about the long-pending and now-very-present climate crisis. The targets and figures are well-trodden ground: the Paris Agreement determined that global warming must be limited to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/clima/policies/international/negotiations/paris_en","children":[{"text":"‘well below’ 2°C"}]},{"text":", which will require a move to net-zero carbon emissions by many of the world’s biggest producers by 2050. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.climatechangenews.com/2019/06/14/countries-net-zero-climate-goal/","children":[{"text":"An increasing number of governments "}]},{"text":"have turned this agreement into national and regional strategy, committing to carbon neutrality through policies like the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/info/strategy/priorities-2019-2024/european-green-deal_en","children":[{"text":"European Green Deal"}]},{"text":", but "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/10/ipcc-climate-change-report-paris-climate-accord-181009134051255.html","children":[{"text":"concerns"}]},{"text":" over whether these targets will even be sufficient to avert the impacts of climate change are ever-growing."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The COVID-19 pandemic has, unexpectedly, illuminated a fork in the road - we have seen the potential for rapid and effective change in action. How we choose to rebuild global economies in the wake of the crisis will determine how our planet and society function for many years to come, and with fast action, we can seize the opportunity to build new economic systems which address the other environmental and humanitarian crises we face."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"New research indicates that none of the 16 largest renewable energy companies"},{"type":"link","url":"https://bit.ly/3cVd3wi","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":" fully meet their basic human rights responsibilities. All 16 score a flat zero on respect for land rights."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The renewable energy industry is absolutely crucial to the fight to stop the climate crisis: without it, we stand no chance of reaching net-zero carbon targets. But the sector, like any other, is susceptible to exploitation. Irresponsible business practices by major companies spearheading the"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-52906551","children":[{"text":" ‘green industrial revolution’ "}]},{"text":"worryingly echo the history of the fossil fuel industries, which have historically abused workers, displaced communities and polluted the environment on a dizzying scale. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593415106/Photo_2_bjgfcr.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Yucatán forest. Image courtesy of Pablo Cabezos. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In Muna, a municipality in the Mexican state of Yucatán, a legal battle is underway over local opposition to a solar energy megaproject looking to clear 603 hectares of forest in order to install 183,000 solar panels. It’s a move local organisations say may put native plant and animal species at risk, as well as impacting the area’s vulnerability to hurricane damage, disrupting pollination processes and contributing to water scarcity. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://files.constantcontact.com/83b41ac7001/80c0c036-82fb-4166-9b19-6f9d64887b28.pdf","children":[{"text":"The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights determined"}]},{"text":" that the consultation process carried out in the village of San José Tipceh - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://en.mexico.pueblosamerica.com/i/san-jose-tipceh/","children":[{"text":"where 70% of the population is indigenous"}]},{"text":", and 35% speak a Maya dialect - for the project by US-based company Sunpower did not comply with international standards. These standards require such projects to have the ‘free, prior and informed consent’ of the indigenous communities they affect. The UN report pointed to irregular payments, conflicts of interest, and ‘culturally inadequate’ attempts to inform local residents of plans; aside from failing to provide translated materials, Sunpower had sent out its technical documents over email, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.cemda.org.mx/consulta-indigena-para-mega-parque-solar-en-muna-yucatan-incumple-estandares-internacionales/","children":[{"text":"inaccessible to members of the community without an internet connection"}]},{"text":". A case brought against the company by Mexican environmental organisation CEMDA is still under litigation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"With plans underway for "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.business-humanrights.org/es/m%C3%A9xico-20-proyectos-de-energ%C3%ADa-renovable-en-proceso-de-consulta-en-la-pen%C3%ADnsula-de-yucat%C3%A1n","children":[{"text":"dozens of renewable energy projects"}]},{"text":" in this area of Mexico alone, local organisations are rightly concerned over shoddy consultation processes opening the door for the potential destruction of swathes of tropical deciduous forest, with local knowledge and understanding of the region’s finely balanced ecosystem taking a backseat to corporate interests."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Beyond the Yucatán peninsula, a pattern of environmental and human rights risks linked to new ‘green’ industries is playing out all over the world as efforts to turn the tide on the climate crisis are ramping up. In Kenya, significant investments in renewable energy production, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.iwgia.org/images/publications//0725_REPORT21.pdf","children":[{"text":"encouraged"}]},{"text":" as part of the country’s sustainable development efforts, have been beset with allegations of human rights abuses. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Lake Turkana Wind Power project is Kenya’s biggest ever private investment ("},{"type":"link","url":"https://old.danwatch.dk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Danwatch_report_A-PEOPLE-IN-THE-WAY-OF-PROGRESS-2016_web.pdf","children":[{"text":"valued at approximately 620 million euros"}]},{"text":"), with electricity generated from turbines reportedly set to increase national energy output by between 15-20%. Since applying for land leases in 2006, the company behind the development claim to have carried out ‘"},{"type":"link","url":"https://old.danwatch.dk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Danwatch_report_A-PEOPLE-IN-THE-WAY-OF-PROGRESS-2016_web.pdf","children":[{"text":"numerous consultations and stakeholder meetings"}]},{"text":"’. However, local communities - including the inhabitants of Sarima village, relocated to a fenced-off enclosure within the project site to make way for 365 turbines produced by Danish manufacturer Vestas - dispute these claims, as documented in a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://old.danwatch.dk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Danwatch_report_A-PEOPLE-IN-THE-WAY-OF-PROGRESS-2016_web.pdf","children":[{"text":"2016 report by Danwatch"}]},{"text":". In a particularly concerning debate, Lake Turkana Wind Power have posited that several of the affected communities cannot be identified as indigenous, and are thus exempt from the usual "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.un.org/development/desa/indigenouspeoples/declaration-on-the-rights-of-indigenous-peoples.html","children":[{"text":"internationally accepted standards "}]},{"text":"on indigenous rights. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593415244/Photo_3_ufj94f.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lake Turkana. Image courtesy of aocrane.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Human rights organisation "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.business-humanrights.org/","children":[{"text":"Business & Human Rights Resource Centre"}]},{"text":" has recorded nearly 200 allegations of abuses related to renewable energy companies all over the world, including killings, threats, land grabs, dangerous working conditions and harm to indigenous peoples’ lives and livelihoods. New research by the organisation indicates that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://bit.ly/3cVd3wi","children":[{"text":"none of the 16 largest renewable energy companies"}]},{"text":" fully meet their basic human rights responsibilities. All 16 score a flat zero on respect for land rights."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Faced with land grabs, intimidation, and abusive working conditions, local communities - who often know first-hand the devastating effects of climate change - are left with no choice but to stand in opposition, sometimes using lawsuits to delay and suspend projects. Kenya’s Lake Turkana project has been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://issafrica.org/iss-today/kenyas-ambitious-wind-turbines-battle-community-land-crosswinds","children":[{"text":"delayed by litigation"}]},{"text":" brought by local communities, but as the Sarima Indigenous People’s Land Forum state in their "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:7b2be4e3-ddf4-4066-987b-6867c8fcab54/download_file?file_format=pdf&safe_filename=FINAL%2BChanging%2BValue%2BLand.pdf&type_of_work=Journal+article","children":[{"text":"declaration"}]},{"text":": "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"'We are not against establishing a wind power project. We know the power of the wind in our ancestral lands, and we want it to contribute to the sustainable development of our communities, the Marsabit County and Kenya as a whole. We are determined to make this happen on the basis of our communities’ ownership and leadership.'","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By undermining the rights and knowledge of the communities who have defended their land and protected the environment for centuries or longer, unscrupulous companies and irresponsible governments put the entire fight to halt the climate crisis at risk. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The answer - as is so often the case - lies in local-led, equity-driven solutions built on meaningful stakeholder engagement. Surrounding communities should be able to reap the benefits of the projects affecting their lives and environments, rather than being choked out by exploitative corporate practices. There are examples of this: in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ejatlas.org/conflict/communal-members-of-ixtepec-contending-to-develop-a-wind-farm-cooperative","children":[{"text":"Oaxaca, Mexico"}]},{"text":", a local wind power project sees 50% of profits reinvested in Ixtepec community projects. In Canada, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://indigenouscleanenergy.com/ice-projects/","children":[{"text":"over 152 renewable energy projects are underway "}]},{"text":"with significant involvement from indigenous stakeholders. But with Business & Human Rights Resource Centre’s new research indicating that only half of the biggest renewable energy companies make any reference at all to the rights of indigenous peoples in their policy statements, there is evidently a long way to go before a future built upon renewable energy becomes truly just and sustainable."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593415328/Photo_4_egqy0e.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ixtepec wind farm cooperative. Image courtesy of Environmental Justice Atlas. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The battle of the climate movement, similar to the work of progressive activists across many spheres, has long been one of fighting to put out the fires of the past. Sustainability extends far beyond measures of carbon emissions and degrees of global warming, and human rights must be at the centre of any path forward which aims to be truly sustainable. Without purposeful action by companies working alongside - rather than against - civil society on climate solutions, supported by pre-emptive and meaningful government regulation, the clean energy industry’s contribution to the climate change battle will only serve to light new fires. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Harriet Wood works as a writer and in digital communications at Business & Human Rights Resource Centre. She writes news, features and the occasional diatribe on social media with a focus on sustainability and human rights. ","italic":true}]}]

title: Divestment: what's the deal?
subtitle: A conversation with People and Planet, who pushed the University of Manchester to divest from fossil fuels.
author: Nicole Wootton-Cane
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Across the world, students are at the heart of the climate justice movement. Both inside and outside of the classroom they are writing, protesting, boycotting, and occupying, attempting to bring about real, meaningful change – and many are starting with their own university campuses as battlegrounds. The idea of facing up to big companies and institutions and demanding change can be daunting. But students are at the core of any university, and through dedicated, organised campaigns, some are beginning to significantly influence shifts in policy at their institutions."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Last November, a group of students from the University of Manchester’s branch of climate campaign network "},{"type":"link","url":"https://peopleandplanet.org/","children":[{"text":"People and Planet"}]},{"text":" hit national news after staging a week-long occupation of a campus administration building, demanding that the university commit to full divestment from fossil fuels. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Six months later their appeal was met with the university’s announcement that they would fully divest from fossil fuel companies by 2022 – a hard won fight for People and Planet, who had been running this campaign at the University for almost nine years."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"\"The power of divestment lies less in the financial impact it has on the fossil fuel industry, which is small, but more in removing its social license to operate.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why is divestment important?  In People and Planet's "},{"type":"link","url":"https://peopleandplanet.org/fossil-free","children":[{"text":"own words"}]},{"text":", it is 'one way we can help to weaken the fossil fuel industry further to support frontline communities in their fight to keep fossil fuels in the ground.' It's about solidarity with those in the Global South whose livelihoods are routinely wrecked by extraction and the effects of climate change. Fossil fuel companies hold five times more carbon in their reserves than we can safely afford to burn to stop runaway climate change, yet are still spending billions searching for more. Our universities are at the forefront of environmental research; this hard work is diminished when the institutions behind it are directly contributing to the problem. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The protest at the University of Manchester appeared straightforward; the students simply refused to leave the building until university senior leadership agreed to meet their seven demands, which as well as divestment included opening up a dialogue with students on the issue, giving regular and public updates on their progress, and a commitment to engaging with issues surrounding climate justice and decolonisation. But similar protests had been tried with little success in the past, and the occupiers knew that intense preparation was required in order to be able to remain in the building for long enough to make the kind of impact they hoped to."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593700738/89278370_2668251666738812_1781182182430081024_o_vpmzhz.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Protestors at UoM. Image courtesy of Fossil Free Manchester. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“The occupation was a mammoth task to plan,” Kate Benson, one of the occupiers, said. “It involved scouting suitable locations (with an accessible toilet!), recruiting enough people to make it viable, making banners and signs and lots of writing: our demands, press releases, an open letter, a legal briefing…”."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kayleigh Crawford, who was responsible for much of the planning, recalled even getting into the building as the hardest part: “18 students trying to inconspicuously enter an off-limits building is never an easy task. We came up with four backup plans in case our original didn’t work, and we ended up using our third backup plan, so being prepared definitely paid off!”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After seven days inside the building, university leadership agreed to come together with the students and discuss their demands. The meeting resulted in an agreement to bring forward a review of the university’s investment portfolio, which at the time had around £12 million worth of shares tied up in fossil fuel reserve and extraction companies. Crucially - thanks to the occupation - during this review, students from People and Planet had a seat at the table."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the new year, a consultation was launched into the future of the University’s investments which received nearly 600 responses from staff, students, and alumni."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“It’s also important because it shows that grassroots student campaigns can work, and helps pave the way for the success of other vital campaigns on campus.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Following this consultation, the University of Manchester recently announced that they will be fully divesting from fossil fuels by 2022. The news means that the University will redistribute the shares they currently have in fossil fuel companies to more sustainable alternatives, and was welcomed as a “huge victory” for People and Planet."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“A divestment win at Manchester, particularly as the largest university in the UK, is important because it piles the pressure on other institutions to follow suit”, Kate told me."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It’s also important because it shows that grassroots student campaigns can work, and helps pave the way for the success of other vital campaigns on campus.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Daniel Johnson, another occupier, said the significance of the decision was twofold. “Firstly, the power of divestment lies less in the financial impact it has on the fossil fuel industry, which is small, but more in removing its social license to operate.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“The second reason for its importance is that the university is finally listening to its students on the climate crisis. People and Planet hope that this will mark a new beginning in which the university can work with its students to reduce its contribution to the climate crisis, cut the last remaining ties with the fossil fuel industry, and further valuable research.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So far 82 UK and 2 Irish universities have committed to divest from fossil fuels in some form. These commitment cover endowment wealth of over £11bn. Has yours? Find out ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://peopleandplanet.org/fossil-free-scorecards","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nicole Wootton-Cane is a recent graduate from the University of Manchester, who has covered student activism for the Guardian and the Mancunion. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Featured image courtesy of Fossil Free UCL. ","italic":true}]}]

title: There are plans to drill for oil on the Isle of Wight
subtitle: Green recovery, anyone?
author: Florence Wildblood
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Isle of Wight was listed as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve this time last year because of its ‘strong tradition of environmental action’ and ecotourism, and its pioneering testing of ‘new measures for climate change mitigation and adaptation’. The island - of which "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.visitisleofwight.co.uk/explore/biosphere-reserve","children":[{"text":"half is"}]},{"text":" an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty - has long been a hub for positive environmental attitudes and action. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Drilling for oil on a self-declared ‘eco-island’ was always bound to cause upset – and is hardly in the spirit of the green recovery we’ve all been looking forward to post-lockdown. Nevertheless, UK Oil and Gas (UKOG) has submitted a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publicaccess.iow.gov.uk/online-applications/applicationDetails.do?activeTab=summary&keyVal=Q7DSVFIQ07V00","children":[{"text":"planning application"}]},{"text":" to the Isle of Wight County Council, hoping to begin a three-year exploratory onshore oil drilling venture at site called ‘Arreton-3-site’, and then to move the drilling to another site in Godshill. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Both Arreton and Godshill are tourist sites; the future of surrounding businesses, and of the Isle of Wight’s tourism industry in general, would be massively threatened by the venture. Expected  environmental impact includes air pollution from diesel-fuelled generators; strain on the island’s already-limited water supply; and the destruction of rural and agricultural land, causing damage to biodiverse ecosystems. In general, the plans demonstrate a cavalier attitude regarding the future of the global climate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"UKOG says the project will have ‘little to no environmental impact’ and will "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-52682041","children":[{"text":"benefit the local economy"}]},{"text":". However, this is disputed by Bea Stark, a lifelong resident of the Isle of Wight who is campaigning to stop the plans from going ahead. Bea is 18 and set up the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/iowprotection/","children":[{"text":"Isle of Wight Protection Group "}]},{"text":"as a means of channeling the discontent of younger island citizens into tangible activism. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593794550/Screen_Shot_2020-07-03_at_17.42.12_ghcxdg.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The IoW Protection Group in action. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As the rules stand, planning permission can only be objected to on technical grounds. But for Bea and the #DontDrillTheWight team, this is about far more than technicalities. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“This proposal, if accepted, will change the island irreversibly, damage tourism, devalue house prices. But most importantly this is an ethical issue. Should we be allowing new onshore oil drilling licenses when we are in a climate emergency?”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“This proposal will determine if our government and councillors actually are seriously committed to their words and pledges to combat climate change and natural resource exploitation,” she says.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bea and her older sister Isabel, who is also campaigning, are optimistic about their efforts - citing previous successes of grassroots activists against the oil and gas industry, such as in the case of UKOG’s application for onshore oil drilling at Markswell Wood, West Sussex. Due to over 2,000 objections from individuals and organisations, UKOG withdrew their planning application just before it was to be debated by the South Downs National Park Authority in May 2017. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Grassroots activists, generally, have a fierce love and loyalty to their home environment. No one knows the surrounding environment and history like locals,\" say the sisters. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"By harnessing both local level knowledge and their drive to protect the environment we truly believe grass roots activism  has the energy and force to stop  oil companies who often overlook local environmental and cultural nuances.\""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the moment, there’s a real lack of public awareness about the drilling proposal, so much so that Isle of Wight Councillor John Medland has labelled it contrary to the principles of democracy. “Forcing such a critical consultation into an exclusively virtual sphere, with no public meetings or documents to handle, is an attack on our very democracy”, he said. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nevertheless, Bea and the team at Don’t Drill the Wight are making progress. They're urging people to submit objections to UKOG’s application, and aiming to get to 2,000 by 24th July. This would match the number of complaints received regarding drilling at Markswell Wood, and would - Bea hopes - constitute a step towards the success seen in Sussex. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Do you want to write an objection? ","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Click ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://publicaccess.iow.gov.uk/online-applications/search.do?action=simple&searchType=Application","children":[{"text":"here","italic":true}]},{"text":" to go to the Isle of Wight Council planning application search page. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Type the reference number into the search bar: 20/00513/FUL. This will take you to the planning application proposal.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"3. Click the ‘Comments’ section, which will show you the Objection and Supporting comments that have already been made. To make a comment, you have to follow the relevant links to register for an account. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Comments can be any length but need to be ","italic":true},{"text":"as specific as possible","italic":true,"bold":true},{"text":".
