title: Climate change is happening where we least expect it
subtitle: Residents of Chicago are feeling the effects of extreme weather as global heating impacts the USA.
author: Elisa Shoenberger
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chicago has always had a reputation for its hot summers and freezing winters, with temperatures sometimes swinging over 100 degrees Fahrenheit in a single year. However, Chicago is not typically part of the conversation when it comes to climate change. Melting sea ice, crumbling glaciers, and uncontrollable wildfires occupy the headlines. But trends over the past few decades suggest that climate change has come to Chicago."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“You see a lot of things that scientists have been warning about manifesting, things like increased flooding... changes in ice freeze, warming winters, hotter summers,” explains Rachel Licker, Senior Climate Scientist for the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ucsusa.org/about/people/rachel-licker","children":[{"text":"Union of Concerned Scientists"}]},{"text":".“We’re seeing the thumbprint of human-caused climate change on the extreme events that have been occurring here.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chicago and the Midwest tend to be absent in national climate discussions because they have not seen hurricanes and wildfires, like those unfolding in other parts of the United States. As Douglas Stotz, senior conservation ecologist at the Field Museum of Chicago, points out “we are affected by the Great Lakes, so continental-wide things tend to be less obvious around Chicago than elsewhere”. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593863844/gettyimages-818701204_2000_vp39ey.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"California wildfires. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, temperatures are warmer than they used to be. Even though Chicago and the Midwest are not facing natural disasters, their changing climate will have repercussions for the entire country. The Midwest as a whole, Rachel says, is “home to a really important agricultural system, producing a lot of the country’s food.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Extreme heat is a real threat – and a reality Chicago is already facing. Rachel, who worked on the Union of Concerned Scientists’ 2019 report "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/killer-heat-united-states-0","children":[{"text":"Killer Heat in the United States"}]},{"text":", points out that while Chicago historically has seen a few days over 100℉ (just under 38℃), it’s “happening more often.” Night-time temperature trends are warmer, thanks to heat absorbed by asphalt, released from engines and then radiated out, which Rachel points out “exacerbates the problem.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While it’s important not to conflate weather and climate, Rachel says, “it’s important to step back to look at the trend, where they have been headed.” If no action is taken by midcentury, the 2019 report predicts that there may be as many as 30 days a year over 100℉ or 53 days by late century. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This extreme heat will adversely impact people living in Chicago and the region, but not proportionally,  since some groups— like the elderly, small children, and under-resourced communities— will face higher risks. Chicago saw how deadly hot summers can be in 1995 when "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-chicago-heat-wave-20-years-later-met-20150715-story.html","children":[{"text":"over 700 people"}]},{"text":" died from a brutal heat wave. While the city has definitely improved its infrastructure and procedures to handle these events, month-long heat waves will put a strain on resources and  “fundamentally change what we could enjoy in the Midwest,” Rachel says."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"The past three Mays have set records for highest rainfall ever "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weather.gov/lot/May_Precip_Rankings_Chicago","children":[{"text":" "}]},{"text":"for the city; each year successively breaks the record. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Extreme heat also increases ozone concentration in cities, which is another significant health risk, the 2019 report explains. “Heat contributes to [ozone] creation”, Rachel explains. Breathing ground-level ozone can result in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.epa.gov/ozone-pollution-and-your-patients-health/health-effects-ozone-general-population","children":[{"text":"damage to respiratory health"}]},{"text":", especially in people who have asthma or similar problems."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But extreme heat isn’t the only change that Chicagoans are currently facing. Winters are becoming warmer and wetter. Rich Kisseloff and Rick Richter, founders of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/Windy-City-Mushers-370560473046323/","children":[{"text":"Windy City Mushers"}]},{"text":", a Chicagoland dog sport group, noted that the past few years are seeing less and less snowfall, impacting dog winter sports. In terms of longer term trends, Rachel sees these observations in line with projections that there will be “more precipitation and less snowfall.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593863942/14479695_802562929846073_5266811239856358682_n_azyzwg.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Winter sports are being affected. Image courtesy of Windy City Mushers. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Precipitation in particular is a salient issue, with scientists predicting and seeing greater storms overall. The 2008"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.chicago.gov/content/dam/city/progs/env/CCAP/CCAP.pdf","children":[{"text":" Chicago Climate Action Plan"}]},{"text":" forecasted that ‘heavy rains and snows could become more frequent in winter and spring.’"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"‘Increased intensity of downpours will make travel more dangerous, flood basements, pollute bodies of water, damage crops, stress the city’s infrastructure and disrupt transportation’, says the plan. ‘During summer, rains may fall more heavily but less frequently, translating to more dry spells as well.’ Rachel suggests that these predictions were, unfortunately, on point. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chicago is seeing “bigger and stronger storms,” Douglas highlights. “The average precipitation has gone up [several] inches since the 1980s.” The past three Mays have set records for "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weather.gov/lot/May_Precip_Rankings_Chicago","children":[{"text":"highest rainfall ever "}]},{"text":"for the city; each year successively breaks the record. However, he says, “precipitation is more of a zero sum game, if it’s wetter in one place, it’s drier someplace else.” June, he points out, has been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weather.gov/lot/June_Precip_Rankings_Chicago","children":[{"text":"drier as a trend"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These warmer winters and springs are also affecting wildlife. Douglas points out that there is a mistiming with birds and when plants start to sprout leaves. Because of the warmer springs, some seasons plants will “leaf out” earlier than the migratory birds may arrive in Chicago. “There is more insect damage to the plants because you don’t have birds eating the insects that are attacking the plants, and the birds don’t forage as much because there is not as much food when they arrive,” he explains. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1593864139/320770754_d57f531c8d_z_lai8gy.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A snowstorm hits Chicago. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"While this mismatch of timing may not be a big deal in a single year, if it becomes a pattern, it spells a lot of problems for the ecosystem. For birds in particular, “when they arrive on their breeding grounds, they are not as not in as good condition,” Douglas explains, “they tend not to do as well breeding.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Douglas also points out that scientists “expect to see changes in distributions of southern species moving into this area,” including invasive species, which can impact farming and quality of life. This year, in particular, is supposed to be a bad year for ticks in the area, he says, “because it didn’t really get cold to knock back the tick population across the winter.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"All of this is very daunting, but Rachel remains hopeful. “There are things we can do right now,” she says. “We can work on reducing greenhouse emissions and make investments in clean energy and infrastructure while improving the energy efficiency of our fleets and home appliances.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We also need to make critical adaptations in our lives to help protect ourselves, and notably the most vulnerable, from events like wildfires, mudslides, and hurricanes. “We need to make sure to build infrastructure that can withstand climate change,” such as improving our energy grids to handle heat waves or building streets and railways to handle these events, Rachel says. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ultimately, “we always have hope that we can come out stronger in the end, it’s going to take perseverance and effort but we need to stick with it all.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Elisa Shoenberger is a writer and journalist living in Chicago. She recently produced ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.stitcher.com/podcast/in-this-climate/e/69098990","children":[{"text":"an audio piece ","italic":true}]},{"text":"on dogsledding and climate change for Indiana University's In This Climate podcast. ","italic":true}]}]

title: Rewilding Pakistan
subtitle: Urban forestry is thriving in the country’s biggest city
author: Anmol Irfan
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Over the last year, Fridays for Future has gained traction, with founder Greta Thunberg even getting an opportunity to speak at the UN. While the campaign does address the climate crisis on a global scale, we cannot expect or ask countries at different stages of economic and social development to react with boundless enthusiasm to its ambitious goals. Nevertheless, many people are working tirelessly in these countries to combat climate change – and focusing only on solutions seen in Western countries gives little visibility to actions being taken in other regions. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pakistan is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.un.org.pk/environment-day/","children":[{"text":"one of the six countries"}]},{"text":" that will be most affected by global warming. Despite Imran Khan’s success in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2018/07/pakistan-s-billion-tree-tsunami-is-astonishing/","children":[{"text":"planting one billion trees"}]},{"text":", there remains much more to be done if the country aims to move towards an environmentally sustainable future. Lack of action by government bodies, particularly those in charge of parks and public spaces, has seen ordinary residents take a stand. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594132091/66286229_10157169930095867_7964935954722979840_n_oy8ikw.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Karim bai Mosque's Urban Forest (Karachi)","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One initiative that really stands out is "},{"type":"link","url":"http://urbanforest.pk/","children":[{"text":"Urban Forest"}]},{"text":", an NGO that uses the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://forestcreators.com/miyawaki-method/","children":[{"text":"Miyawaki method"}]},{"text":" to plant groupings of native trees in small areas. The Miyawaki method involves planting different species of trees in a small pit, thus allowing them to grow at a pace ten times faster than normal. Urban Forest was brought to life in Karachi after "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-33358705","children":[{"text":"more than 1000 citizens"}]},{"text":" in the city lost their lives in the 2015 heatwave. The organisation aims to restore some of the natural wildlife of the city and prevent future heat waves by planting forests that can eventually become self-sustainable. Even if the organisation manages to form just 25 urban forests in the city,"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" it would be able to get rid of the urban heat island (UHI) effect that is formed in urban areas when human activity causes an unnatural rise in the surrounding temperature."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I spoke to founder Shahzad Qureshi about his thoughts on what needs to be done about the climate crisis in Pakistan. Where the problem lies, Shahzad emphasises, is in thinking that our responsibility ends with using one less straw or planting one sapling. “I am fond of improving the environment as an individual, whereas my services [ie. urban forestry] are available for anyone if they need my assistance”, he adds."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594131993/20934057_10155441538890867_1974841269053003257_o_nekl4p.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The community come together to be a part of the planting effort (Lahore)  ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Trees must be integrated into urban planning, Shahzad feels, but not just as pretty greenery. The kind of planting and growth we need is about understanding native species, and the benefits they can offer us - and each other - when given the right environment. Our gardens and parks contain self-sustaining ecosystems; we can’t just get rid of the plants within them when they become ‘unsightly’. Spacing trees far apart for aesthetic purposes greatly limits the environmental benefits they can bring. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Though the benefit of trees, particularly those planted using the Miyawaki method, in urban settings is undeniable - according to the organisation, ‘these forests can capture more carbon and address the urgency to restore ecosystems that encourage biodiversity’ - Urban Forest has certainly faced a few obstacles. It has been difficult to garner the support of local people, and also to work with government organisations. Despite the fact that the organisation currently has "},{"type":"link","url":"http://urbanforest.pk/projects/","children":[{"text":"seven active projects"}]},{"text":", many still do not understand what is needed to support forest growth. For example - Shahzad articulates - Urban Forest felt the need to adopt one park and work on it in a private capacity so as to achieve what they wanted to with the space. The team found that most people were wary of investing in this project since they felt they weren’t getting enough recognition out of it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, slowly but surely people are understanding and supporting the cause. The organisation has now expanded and created similar forests in housing areas in Lahore, and Shahzad says that an increasing number of people have started reaching out and asking to join. Following in the footsteps of Indian ‘eco-preneur’ "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ted.com/speakers/shubhendu_sharma","children":[{"text":"Shubhendu Sharma"}]},{"text":", who has used the same principles to plant small-scale, maintenance-free and biodiverse forests all over India with Urban Forest’s partner Afforest, Shahzad’s trees and tree-planters could signal big things for Pakistan and its boiling hot cities. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594132279/20988150_10155441535670867_6787756606321939924_o_gjeo8z.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shubhendu Sharma at Lahore's first Urban Forest, Dream Gardens. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Anmol Irfan is the founder and editor of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/theperspectivemag/","children":[{"text":"Perspective Magazine","italic":true}]},{"text":", an online magazine and community platform that explores South Asian society through a lens of feminism and empowerment.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/groups/urbanforestpakistan/","children":[{"text":"Urban Forest","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: Making local food work for everyone
subtitle: A food hub in Portland is solving the business and logistical challenges of local food – and helping small farmers become a big deal.
author: Hannah Wallace
content: [{     "type":"paragraph",     "children":[         {             "text":"This article was originally published by ",             "italic": true         },         {             "type":"link",             "url":"https://sojoexchange.squarespace.com/home/how-portland-makes-local-food-work-for-everyone",             "children":[                 {                     "text":"the Solutions Journalism Exchange",                     "italic": true                 }             ]         },         {             "text":" and ",             "italic": true         },         {             "type":"link",             "url":"https://reasonstobecheerful.world/the-redd-portland-local-food-hub-small-farms/",             "children":[                 {                     "text":"Reasons to be Cheerful",                     "italic": true                 }             ]         },         {             "text":".",             "italic": true         }     ] },{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It’s Friday afternoon, and people on bikes and in cars are pulling up to an enormous red-brick warehouse in Portland’s Central Eastside to pick up their “Greater Good” boxes. Packed with local food, the $50 boxes are organized by local grocery chain New Seasons and wholesaler "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.hannahmwallace.com/hannahs_clips/2014/07/an-interview-with-david-lively-at-organically-grown-co.html","children":[{"text":"Organically Grown Co"}]},{"text":". A similar pick-up parade occurs on Wednesdays, when people cart away \""},{"type":"link","url":"https://localdockbox.com/","children":[{"text":"Dock Boxes"}]},{"text":"\" of fish, shrimp and crab from popular Oregon Coast seafood restaurant Local Ocean. And on Monday evenings, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.farmpunksalads.com/","children":[{"text":"Farm Punk"}]},{"text":", a farm in nearby Gresham, drops off its 50 community-supported agriculture (CSA) shares here, to be delivered the next day to eaters’ front porches via electric-assist trikes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is the “new normal” at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ecotrust.org/project/the-redd-on-salmon-street/","children":[{"text":"the Redd on Salmon"}]},{"text":", an enterprise that’s optimizing Portland’s local food system and helping farmers, ranchers and fisherfolk adapt to a post-Covid reality. Even in the before times, the Redd on Salmon served as a solution to the infrastructure dilemma for small and mid-size farmers, who face all kinds of logistical challenges as they try to get food to consumers. Without the production volume to justify large-scale storage and transport systems, small farmers often spend a full day on the road each week, burning precious time and money driving to restaurants and supermarkets, dropping off their wares one at a time. They also need to market and often sell their own goods — skills many farmers don’t know the first thing about. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Redd solves all these problems in one fell swoop, acting as a distribution hub, an affordable storage space and a shared industrial kitchen. Ecotrust, the environmental think tank behind the Redd, also hosts a business accelerator, helping small farmers to scale up. Currently, the Redd supports more than 150 small to mid-size food-related businesses. From 2018 to 2019, the facility’s core tenants saw a 45 percent increase in job creation and a 12 percent increase in jobs at or above the living wage. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Medium-sizing small farms","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Covid-19 pandemic has exposed the failures of the industrial food system. Grocery stores have run short of pasta, canned beans, flour, yeast and meat. Farmers, unable to sell to school cafeterias and chain restaurants, are "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/11/business/coronavirus-destroying-food.html","children":[{"text":"dumping their milk and plowing under their onions"}]},{"text":". When "},{"type":"link","url":"https://thefern.org/2020/05/the-workers-are-being-sacrificed-as-cases-mounted-meatpacker-jbs-kept-people-on-crowded-factory-floors/?fbclid=IwAR2ukJWE8eU_ZBBjwB03EgyWdTXf_PdHaoxxqoFW9iX0O7gwhTpSwGPMpHk","children":[{"text":"20 gargantuan meat processing plants "}]},{"text":"were shuttered by coronavirus outbreaks, farmers were left with no choice but to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/14/business/coronavirus-farmers-killing-pigs.html","children":[{"text":"euthanize hundreds of thousands of pigs and millions of chickens"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As Michael Pollan noted in his "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2020/06/11/covid-19-sickness-food-supply/?utm_source=FERN+Newsletter+Service&utm_campaign=35fddf6479-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2019_07_09_08_03_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_c95f7f9b8b-35fddf6479-120474065","children":[{"text":"recent piece in "},{"text":"the New York Review of Books","italic":true}]},{"text":", our industrial food chain is broken, but local food systems, like the one championed and supported by the Redd on Salmon, are proving to be more resilient. “The advantages of local food systems have never been more obvious, and their rapid growth during the past two decades has at least partly insulated many communities from the shocks to the broader food economy,” Pollan writes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Redd on Salmon is an integral part of this system. It is what is known as a food hub, a centrally located space that facilitates the aggregation, storage, processing, distribution and/or marketing of regionally produced food products. Not only does the block-long space provide farmers a 2,000-square-foot cold storage facility (half freezer, half refrigeration), it has offices and “dry storage” space so local companies like Ground Up PDX (nut butters) and Hoss Sauce (hot sauce) can stash boxes and product at a central location closer to their customers. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Redd solves the transport conundrum, too, with its main tenant, B-Line. A short-haul service with a fleet of electric-assist trikes, B-Line executes “last-mile” delivery without spewing carbon dioxide or jamming up the roads at delivery sites. Trike drivers load up their insulated trailers with up to 600 pounds of product and drop off food at restaurants, grocery stores and corporate cafeterias like AirBnB and Google. (B-Line also has one truck for deliveries that are further than three miles away. Founder and CEO Franklin Jones is saving up for an electric one.)  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By providing an all-in-one distribution hub to farmers who could never afford one on their own, the Redd was conceived as a way to support what food systems experts call “the agriculture of the middle.” Ag of the middle producers are larger than those who sell via local farmers’ markets or CSAs, but smaller than those supplying globalized commodity markets. With logistical and marketing support from the Redd, these producers can scale up and eventually serve institutional outlets like schools, hospitals, grocery stores and corporate offices."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And lest you think this is a quirky boutique solution unique to Portlandia, know that there are over 350 food hubs around the country—from Durham, North Carolina to "},{"type":"link","url":"http://cherrycapitalfoods.com/","children":[{"text":"Traverse City, Michigan"}]},{"text":". A "},{"type":"link","url":"https://civileats.com/2016/06/20/want-to-launch-the-next-food-hub-heres-what-you-need-to-know/","children":[{"text":"traditional food hub "}]},{"text":"offers aggregation, marketing and often distribution for agricultural products. It might also serve as an incubator for micro-businesses. But the Redd takes it a step further, offering shared kitchens, a co-working space and even (across the street in the Redd East) an 8,000-square-foot event space with a state-of-the-art kitchen. Jim Barham, an agricultural economist at the USDA, calls the Redd a food hub on steroids."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Founded by Ecotrust, which has long been a champion of ag of the middle producers, the Redd runs a two-year "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ecotrust.org/project/ag-of-the-middle/","children":[{"text":"Ag of the Middle Accelerator Program"}]},{"text":" that helps smaller-scale farmers, ranchers and fisherfolk learn the basics of marketing, accounting, taxation and business structure — as well as helping them apply for "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.rd.usda.gov/programs-services/value-added-producer-grants","children":[{"text":"USDA value-added producer grants"}]},{"text":". As part of their orientation, participants in the accelerator tour the Redd’s facilities; graduates often end up using the space in some way. Over 70 producers have either graduated from the accelerator program or are in it right now. The current cohort of 17 businesses increased their sales by $1.5 million, collectively, after one year in the program. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Keeping it local","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pre-pandemic, 30 to 40 percent of B-Line’s deliveries were to restaurants, corporate cafeterias or downtown businesses like Office Depot. Now that most of those are closed, the company has had to pivot, doing more frequent deliveries to New Seasons’ 18 area grocery stores, as well as serving as a physical hub for new direct-to-consumer services like the DockBox and Greater Good boxes. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“When the pandemic hit, there was a flurry of ‘panic buying,’” says B-Line founder and CEO Franklin Jones. As it did at many supermarket chains, demand skyrocketed at New Seasons, causing a backlog with mainline distributors like KeHE, UNFI and Supervalu. As a result, says director of brand development at New Seasons Chris Tjersland, these distributors limited the amount of product that could be shipped to each store, leaving them with empty shelves. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But because B-Line has pre-existing relationships with local farmers and producers, Jones was able to funnel products straight from these vendors through the Redd and into the aisles at New Seasons. Working with B-Line also allowed Tjersland and Jones to work directly with the producers of New Seasons’s private label line at a moment when traditional distribution channels were breaking down. While industrial farms were dumping perfectly good fruit and milk, B-Line was storing and delivering thousands of cases of Shepherd’s Grain flour, 800 cases of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.rallentipasta.com/about-1","children":[{"text":"Rallenti Pasta "}]},{"text":"and over 400 cases of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://scenicfruit.com/","children":[{"text":"Scenic Fruit"}]},{"text":" frozen berries. Tjersland even worked with local companies Brew Dr Kombucha and Straightaway Cocktails to make "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.brewdrkombucha.com/uncategorized/how-were-transforming-a-byproduct-of-kombucha-into-hand-sanitizer/","children":[{"text":"New Seasons hand sanitizer"}]},{"text":", which was stored at the Redd and delivered via B-Line. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The pandemic prompted other positive developments at the Redd. Redd Campus Manager Emma Sharer was tasked with how to optimize the Redd East event space, normally booked with weddings, natural wine fairs and food-focused conferences. In late March, she was doing an ab workout on the waterfront when she ran into Jacobsen Valentine, founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://civileats.com/2020/02/10/feed-the-mass-aims-to-bring-affordable-cooking-classes-to-everyone/","children":[{"text":"Feed the Mass"}]},{"text":", an affordable cooking school that teaches people how to make healthy meals from scratch."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The two struck up a conversation. “He was like, ‘My nonprofit is really struggling and I have this idea: how can we make meals for people who are missing access to them? Who are forced to buy fast food or packaged food?” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"They cooked up a collaborative plan. Ecotrust would donate its Redd East kitchen to Valentine two days a week, and he would cook meals for unhoused and food insecure folks around town.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://ecotrust.org/feeding-communities-during-a-crisis/","children":[{"text":"The FED Project "}]},{"text":"was born. For the past month, Valentine and a handful of volunteers have been cooking two meals a week at the Redd’s kitchen; each meal can feed 200 people. The meals are packed up individually and delivered to folks around town who need them. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ecotrust gave Valentine a small food budget and stipend. Plus, Sharer scored a huge food donation from Airbnb when the company’s Portland offices, including its cafeteria, closed in March. Since the company had been sourcing via the Redd, much of the food was high-quality and local. “There was cheese, sour cream, Camas Country flour, a lot of spices, chicken from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.marionacres.com/","children":[{"text":"Marion Acres"}]},{"text":", pork products from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.campfirefarms.com/","children":[{"text":"Campfire Farm"}]},{"text":", confit garlic, frozen berries,” says Airbnb’s food program manager Abby Fammartino, who estimates that the donation was worth $10,000 in total. Jacobsen and his crew made mac and cheese the first week and channa masala the next. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sharer and Valentine hope that this particular project will live on even after the pandemic is over. “If we were to get more funding, could some of that go towards paying BIPOC (Black, Indigenous and People of Color) farmers to purchase more product, supportive of the sourcing side of farming?” asks Sharer. “That’s our next step.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One thing is clear: the Redd campus — and its robust local food community — helped keep flour and hand sanitizer on New Seasons shelves while mainline distributors couldn’t keep up with the spike in demand. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“What it [the pandemic] made me realize is that the supply chain infrastructure is broken,” Tjersland from New Seasons says. Jones, who hasn’t had to lay off anyone at B-Line as a result of his increased business with New Seasons, agrees. “The whole pandemic really shone a spotlight on how resilient the local supply chain could be.” "}]}]

title: Monopoly money for the rich
subtitle: Carbon offsetting has become a get-out-of-jail free card.
author: Esmé Audland
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In recent years it has been hailed as "},{"text":"the","italic":true},{"text":" thing to do, but the commercialisation of carbon offsetting has unsurprisingly become a get-out-of-jail free card for the rich. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Marketing campaigns sell it as a ‘quick-fix’, a trade-off for yet another holiday this year, a way to excuse immodest lifestyles. The "},{"text":"click here to offset your carbon emissions ","italic":true,"bold":true},{"text":"box is the most dangerous marketing tool of all. Responsibility immediately shifts off of the shoulders of the consumer. Thousands are forked out, and then you're given a gold star for donating the price of lunch at the local deli on top. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But how many people actually know how their carbon is offset? Before ticking that box, who actually takes the time to calculate how long it will be before said scheme can compensate for your flight?"}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Simply put, we need to increase the number of schemes to offset carbon, but more importantly we need to reduce our global carbon emissions by 45% by 2030 - as per the UN Environmental Programme. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carbon offset schemes were born out of the need to balance the emissions equation, allowing the largest polluters to compensate for their actions. Undoubtedly these schemes are necessary if we are to even have a shot at fixing the climate crisis. However, while a useful tool for industries making the transition to alternative energy and new technology, carbon offsetting is not the answer to the climate crisis. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For the wealthy, carbon offsetting is affordable. At "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.goldstandard.org/take-action/offset-your-emissions","children":[{"text":"Gold Standard"}]},{"text":", for example, forest regeneration projects average €13 per tonne CO². For those who have everything, this cost won’t make a dent. This transaction is as impactful as the loss of Monopoly money, and the consumer is removed from responsibility by a degree of separation. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594402814/marcin-jozwiak-NdMcz5d74Ak-unsplash_kk4vtt.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We need to stop creating emissions in the first place. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://landlifecompany.com","children":[{"text":"Land Life Company"}]},{"text":" carry out successful carbon offsetting programmes, including the reforestation of 50 hectares of degraded land in Northern Spain. This specific scheme invests 65% of total investment into local procurement and will capture 8,328 tonnes of carbon over 30 years. But to understand why carbon offsetting cannot be the answer we need to put these numbers in perspective:"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Globally we emit (at least) 36 billion tonnes of CO² per year "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. For argument’s sake, let’s say every project sequesters 8,328 tonnes of carbon over 30 years. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"3. To combat one year of carbon emissions we would need 4,322,767 more of these projects."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"4. And it would still take those projects 30 years to capture all the carbon produced in one year. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"5. Ultimately, trees that are planted today cannot grow fast enough. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Read that again. Let that sink in. ","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On top of this, carbon offsetting - if carried out irresponsibly - can cause immediate "},{"text":"damage","italic":true},{"text":". "},{"text":"Ours to Save","italic":true},{"text":" "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=ckbl9gi8m005b0712nijhqv53","children":[{"text":"recently reported"}]},{"text":" on the effect of carbon offsetting by several Norway-based companies; they bought and ‘conserved’ forest in East Africa, but at the cost of forced eviction and food scarcity for thousands of local people. Countries that have barely contributed to the climate crisis are already bearing the brunt of it; we need to ensure this pattern does not recur with carbon offsetting. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By no means should carbon offsetting be stopped. The replantation of forests, peat bogs, marshes and other habitats is essential work, and so important in reestablishing ecosystems. Simply put, we need to increase the number of schemes to offset carbon, but more importantly we need to reduce our global carbon emissions by 45% by 2030 (according to the UN Environmental Programme). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We need to shift our perceptions of carbon. Emissions may not be a tangible concept to those that live a sheltered existence in the financial capitals of the world, but to the millions of climate refugees displaced each year it is very real. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We live in a global society where travel is normalised. It is unrealistic to assume the world will stop flying tomorrow, but attitudes do need to change. Carbon offsetting is slowing this process down; the option to feel better about our behaviour is preventing us from changing it for good. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Esmé Audland is an English student at UCL. Passionate about environmental sustainability and plant-based eating, she works in marketing for the new vegan restaurant directory ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sayplants.com/","children":[{"text":"SayPlants! ","italic":true}]},{"text":"and promotes delicious, low-impact cuisine at ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://deliciouslyella.com/","children":[{"text":"Deliciously Ella","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594402465/eric-muhr-W0Yp5uk2UnQ-unsplash_lynuqv.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]}]

title: Impact Investing
subtitle: Private sector capital is vital in the fight against climate change.
author: Jack Isaacs
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The fight against climate change has been one of few things to have benefited from the COVID-19 lockdown. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.globalcarbonproject.org/news/TemporaryReductionInCO2EmissionsDuringCOVID-19.html","children":[{"text":"The Global Carbon Project"}]},{"text":" has shown that carbon emissions may see an overall reduction of 7% in 2020 and, in certain countries, were down by an average of 26% during the peak of the pandemic. These are good statistics but Rome wasn’t built in a day and climate change won’t be conquered in 2020. The cumulative cost of repairing the environmental damage committed in the last century will be far more than whatever global governments have left in their coffers in the aftermath of a global lockdown. In a world where nothing comes for free and the public sector is running low on cash, impact investors are waiting patiently on the side lines."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://thegiin.org/impact-investing/need-to-know/#what-is-impact-investing","children":[{"text":"The Global Impact Investing Network"}]},{"text":" defines impact investments as, ‘investments made with the intention to generate positive, measurable social or environmental impact alongside a financial return.’ In simpler terms, whilst traditional investors focus solely on maximising profits, impact investors apply the same criteria to their investments but with the added objective of solving a social or environmental issue. Before delving into how impact investing can help in the climate crisis, we must first consider where it fits amongst the conglomerate of other technical terms thrown around by the financial sector to demonstrate its commitment to a fairer and cleaner planet earth. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bridgesfundmanagement.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Bridges-Spectrum-of-Capital-screen.pdf","children":[{"text":"The Bridges Spectrum of Capital"}]},{"text":", developed by one of the UK’s leading impact fund managers, conveys this better than most:"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594630170/jack_isaacs_ctclfg.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" Figure 1: The Bridges Spectrum of Capital. Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bridgesfundmanagement.com/","children":[{"text":"Bridges Fund Management","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On the far left of the table above we have those who focus solely on maximising profits, with no regard for the social or environmental impact of their investment decisions. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sustainable/responsible investors are those who’ve realised that investing in organisations that perpetuate environmental and social degradation may not be great for business or their reputation. They use Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) factors to reduce the likelihood of making unethical investment decisions and to ensure that they maintain a fair working environment within their own ranks. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Finally, we have impact investing, which has a spectrum all to itself. This ranges from ‘financial first investors’, who seek to make at least a market-rate of return alongside creating a social or environmental impact, to ‘impact first investors’, who are willing to make some financial sacrifice in order to address a societal challenge. My expectation and hope is that with time and the correct motivation, investors and businesses alike will continue to shift right across this table, to a point where impact investors are the only constituents."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How does all this equate to fighting climate change? The most important players when it comes to making a positive environmental impact are not the investors themselves, rather their investees. For example, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://boweryfarming.com/","children":[{"text":"Bowery Farming"}]},{"text":" raised "},{"type":"link","url":"https://boweryfarming.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/360049977434-Who-is-invested-in-Bowery-","children":[{"text":"more than $172.5 million"}]},{"text":" from several investors for their smart, indoor farms that save water, reduce pesticides and improve access to locally grown produce. Organisations such as these have the potential to generate large-scale returns, whilst providing an alternative to the existing unsustainable behaviours within the agriculture industry. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594630717/Crispy_Leaf_Lettuces_jwcoll.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bowery is the modern indoor farming company growing food for a better future. Image courtesy of Bowery. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Additionally, impact-first investors such as "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.socialandsustainable.com/","children":[{"text":"Social and Sustainable Capital"}]},{"text":" have demonstrated the potential for creating positive environmental impact at a more local level. An "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.socialandsustainable.com/cases/plymouth-energy-community","children":[{"text":"investment in the Plymouth Energy Community "}]},{"text":"allowed for a community owned solar farm to be built on local derelict brownfield land. Not only has this generated enough renewable energy for 1000 homes annually but the rental payments will help to support regeneration activities in the local area. High impact organisations would be severely limited in their ability to operate sustainably without investments such as these. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Climate change has numerous causes and presents an abundance of issues for the natural world. There is no one size fits all solution. Consequently, different solutions need to be financed in different ways. Governments have a toolbox with which to fix social and environmental issues but have thus far been reluctant to use all their tools. Government funding, private sector capital and philanthropy are all financing methods with their own benefits and limitations and will all be needed in the fight against climate change. The private sector will play a fundamental role in this fight, where for-profit businesses can provide solutions at a scale that is simply out of reach within a government or philanthropic budget. If there’s one thing that can be said about capitalism, it’s that it is very good at creating capital. That capital needs to be directed towards solving both climate change and the mounting social issues that continue to grow following COVID-19. Impact investing facilitates that need."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" Jack Isaacs is a graduate in Social Sciences from the University of Bath. He has done extensive research on the UK’s social impact investing sector and is especially interested in how alternative methods of funding and for-profit business models can be used to alleviate social and environmental challenges.","italic":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594631179/anne-nygard-OtqaCE_SEMI-unsplash_hctuad.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]}]

title: Innovation Station
subtitle: A conversation with Peter Okwoko, the Ugandan eco-entrepreneur making face shields sustainable.
author: Eliza Scott
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In May, I "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ourstosave.com/feature?id=cka6gqrs9000r07827twog1qd","children":[{"text":"wrote something"}]},{"text":" for "},{"text":"Ours to Save ","italic":true},{"text":"about Takataka Plastics - a Ugandan organisation innovating with plastic waste and, during the COVID-19 pandemic, making recycled face shields. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In June, I sat down in front of my computer to talk to Peter Okwoko, the co-founder of Takataka and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://hashtaggulu.org/","children":[{"text":"Hashtag Gulu"}]},{"text":" and the founder of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/AfriGreenSustain/","children":[{"text":"AfriGreen Sustain"}]},{"text":". When we spoke, Peter and his team had just donated 180 face shields to the Lira Regional Hospital. I was keen to know more. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594806755/0_iuznvl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Peter Okwoko. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For those not yet in the know, could you describe what you do with Takataka Plastics?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I first met Paige [Balcom] two years ago when she was doing research and by then I was teaching ICT and computer science at the university. I had already founded AfriGreen Sustain. A year later, someone again connected us again. A friend in the US told me about a lady who was passionate about helping the environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"When she came back [to Uganda] we started doing research and experimenting with different kinds of plastic waste. We founded Takataka Plastics with the main goal of recycling plastic waste. We started in Gulu, and our target is to recycle up to nine tons of plastic waste every month. We then turn the plastic into construction materials. When COVID-19 affected business in Uganda, we started making face shields."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why did you feel that it was important to start your companies in Uganda?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I love my country and we have a lot of challenges. I liked that I could use the knowledge I obtained in Denmark to come back home to it. When I came back to Uganda, I thought we could figure out the plastic waste on a local level. The major thing that we were looking at was how to change mindsets. We reached out to different primary schools and started eco-clubs, where kids are taught how to up-cycle. They learned how to make briquettes to cook with. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What has been your experience working within an eco-organisation in Uganda and what has the reception been like locally and from the government?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"From local government, they have been welcoming – their offices are always open. When we started our "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.takatakaplastics.com/blog/greening-gulu-through-monthly-community-clean-ups-makegulugreen","children":[{"text":"Make Gulu Green initiative"}]},{"text":", they vowed to take over following our first few months of work. There are also improvements nationally as the Environmental Act, which was super old, now has new articles geared towards promoting sustainability."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594806845/88236447_3416864021678340_837094237001482240_n_f3vmr0.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/AfriGreenSustain/photos/a.1872201882811236/3416864018345007/?type=3&theater","children":[{"text":"AfriGreen Sustain","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How have you personally witnessed the effects of climate change, and what is the public perception of it?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There is still a lack of knowledge about the value of plastic waste. In Gulu, as in most cities in developing countries, people just litter. There is also a lack of sorting mechanisms for different categories of waste. People are not aware of the fumes released. Because of that, in the beginning of this year we started ‘Make Gulu Green’ with schools. This involves monthly community clean-up activities. We teach them about the different categories of waste and how to sort it. We continue to reach out to schools and we show people alternatives to single use plastics. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Since COVID hit we were unable to go ahead with that [project]. We also have been trying to harness the power of the internet and use radios to promote awareness."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"You also work on plastic waste reduction with your company AfriGreen Sustain and work with people who live on the streets with Hashtag Gulu. Could you tell me about your path to creating these companies?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I started with Hashtag Gulu, a community-led organisation, which I began while studying in Denmark after a friend posted a photo of children on the streets. I thought that we could take action beyond social media. We reunited some children with their parents. I also gave three young people shelter for a year then reunited them with their families. We decided to go forward and create the organisation in 2018. This year we got some grants which will enable us to upskill 50 street-connected children and young adults. They will be taught carpentry, construction and tailoring. When COVID-19 hit, it was challenging but we managed to continue to shelter all of them and continue on with teaching. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"AfriGreen started in 2016 with the aim of changing [people’s] mindsets. We held workshops and started campaigns. However, changing mindsets was one thing, but creating job opportunities and transforming waste was another. With Takataka Plastics, we want to create 30 jobs in a year for street-connected kids. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The beauty was that we already had Hashtag Gulu, which was working well with the kids. We were able to offer some of them jobs and provide them with psycho-social support. So far, we have recruited seven. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Where do you see your work going in the next 5 years?","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I see Takataka expanding to different municipalities in Uganda as well as other East African countries like Kenya, South Sudan and Tanzania. I can see the company employing over 100 people that would otherwise be on the street."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After the success of the face-shields, we want to create a unit that specifically makes plastic medical equipment; we have realised that a lot of medical equipment that can be made out of plastic. I also want to get involved in low-cost energy."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lastly, do you have any advice for our readers about how to make more sustainable choices?","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We should not use wasteful products when we can. In instances where they are essential, we should try to reduce our consumption. We need to carry through with our ideals – to walk the walk. We need the drops in the ocean, for example saying ‘I refuse to use one plastic bag today’. That is enough."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1594806733/Screen_Shot_2020-07-15_at_10.51.56_ygl52w.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On 4th July, Takataka donated 150 face shields to Moyo District Local Government COVID-19 Taskforce. title: 'No fashion on a dead planet'
subtitle: I quit my dream career in fashion at 25. I know recent allegations about Boohoo are just the tip of the iceberg.
author: Katie Brown
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"When we choose what to wear, we are choosing how we express ourselves. For many of us, our clothing gives insight into our personality, character and mood more than any other medium. Its transformative abilities are unparalleled. I studied Fashion Management at university and scraped through a year of unpaid internships in order to become a fashion buyer, and that’s what I did for four years. In March 2020, I quit. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The job took its toll both physically and mentally. I was chronically stressed, underweight, underpaid and anxious. The impact I knew my industry was having on both people and the planet created a real moral dichotomy. I found it grossly unfair that it was necessary for others to suffer in order to satisfy the whims and pressures of modern living. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2017, WRAP reported that in the UK, 38 million items of new clothing were bought each week, while 11 million were sent to landfill in that same time period. That is the equivalent value of around £140 million of clothing sent to landfill each year. I couldn’t justify the job to myself any longer. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595009862/fast-fashion-moda-a_wxb9b2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The #BoycottBoohoo campaign sprung into action on Instagram in July 2020, as a reaction to an "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/boohoos-sweatshop-suppliers-they-only-exploit-us-they-make-huge-profits-and-pay-us-peanuts-lwj7d8fg2","children":[{"text":"undercover report by "},{"text":"The Sunday Times","italic":true}]},{"text":", which asserted that garment workers in Leicester - making clothes for Boohoo and associated brands - were forced to work through the COVID-19 pandemic. They were also reportedly paid as little as £3.50 per hour, significantly less than half national minimum wage. Many are drawing links between the high COVID-19 infection rates in pockets of the UK such as Leicester and the presence of fast fashion factories. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The #BoycottBoohoo campaign saw the brand berated by the online community. They were called out on their alleged practices, as well as their insipid response to "},{"text":"The Sunday Times","italic":true},{"text":"' allegations. Realistically, I'd anticipate that we are nowhere near the end of this saga – and that there are many more brands yet to be rumbled by the omnipotent online environmental army. Quiz, another brand with the same low-price strategy, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://internetretailing.net/strategy-and-innovation/strategy-and-innovation/quiz-is-latest-fast-fashion-retailer-to-review-its-supply-chain-amid-low-pay-allegations-21695","children":[{"text":"has already launched an investigation"}]},{"text":" into its supply chain for the same reasons. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Even accounting for economies of scale, it’s extremely unlikely that a garment can be made ethically while retailing for less than £10."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The rush to avoid the same fate as Boohoo is evident. But is cutting ties with these factories the correct way forward? Could brands not work alongside factories to improve the quality of the working environment, and ensure minimum wage is paid? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Where will these brands now move production to? If they choose another factory that can match the prices of their previous supplier, what’s to say the working conditions won’t be the same there? Is it the responsibility of the brand to monitor production standards? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another hashtag gaining traction online - one that also responds to the fashion industry walking away from its obligations in the midst of a global pandemic - is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.supportgarmentworkers.org/payup-fashion","children":[{"text":"#PayUp"}]},{"text":". As Traidcraft "},{"type":"link","url":"https://action.traidcraft.org.uk/fast-fashion-crisis-take-action","children":[{"text":"puts it"}]},{"text":", ‘UK fashion brands are cancelling orders with no notice and devastating the lives of workers in poor countries’. The Business & Human Rights Resource Centre surveyed 35 global fashion brands on how they’re protecting their workers during COVID-19 and found that 40% - including "},{"type":"link","url":"https://covid19.business-humanrights.org/en/companies/arcadia-group/?issue=328","children":[{"text":"Arcadia Group"}]},{"text":" (who own Topshop, Topman, Miss Selfridge and others) - made ‘no public commitment to pay for all completed orders’. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595010042/Topshop_1_zj7gdx.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Clearly, the problem is bigger than one dodgy factory. The COVID-19 crisis is exposing the cracks in the intricate web which conceals the production lines of many fast fashion businesses. It’s no secret within the industry that in order to sell clothes cheaply, they need to be made cheaply. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In my experience, the profit margin of a fashion retail business is usually somewhere between 40% and 60%. The cost of making a garment would therefore need to be around half of the retail price. The ‘make price’ needs to include all elements of a finished garment, including: fabric, trims (buttons, zips, etc.), care labels, swing tags, transport and labour. Even accounting for economies of scale, it’s extremely unlikely that a garment can be made ethically while retailing for less than £10."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"The supply chains in these cases are so complicated and carefully woven that it is almost impossible to point the finger at any one culprit. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As an ex-buyer, I know that these margins are non-negotiable. They inform the profit and loss account of a business. They also dictate the performance forecast, which in turn informs investors and share price. When a brand like Boohoo is found to be exploiting garment workers, it shouldn’t cause them to be “shocked and appalled” or “saddened”. Their business is built on the very premise of low cost labour. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The supply chains in these cases are so complicated and carefully woven that it is almost impossible to point the finger at any one culprit. Brands can easily pass blame onto factory owners, or claim that consumer demand is fuelling the market for excessive production and consumption. The UK government has done its best to shirk involvement in legislation, quashing numerous progressive reforms in recent months. This seems to be the crux of the issue; "},{"text":"if no one is responsible, who can fix the problem? ","bold":true}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595009865/karina-tess-H14pfhlfr24-unsplash_vh0crp.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Truly, there are no simple fixes in fast fashion. Changes need to come from inside the industry, both from individual employees and from top level management. Governments must take action, and consumers also have a part to play. ‘Voting’ with your money is the strongest signal that can be sent to a profit-driven business. A shift of consumer mindset away from mass consumption and towards valuing quality would also have a seismic effect on the market itself. Investors have power, and are at last waking up to the long term damage the climate crisis will cause to their portfolios. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The fast fashion revolution has been well underway for some time, outrage bubbling away in many forms. To see brands responding - albeit out of fear - to these campaigns is a big step. If the events of the last week are anything to go by, I have hope that the pot might start to boil over, and that the reforms we so desperately need will begin to come into play – especially if the media continues to use its influence to inform positive change, and consumers continue to apply pressure. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"If you’re wondering what can be done on an individual level, I’d urge you to keep it simple. I swear by "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/membership/video/2014/oct/29/vivienne-westwood-capitalism-clothing-video","children":[{"text":"the wise words"}]},{"text":" of Vivienne Westwood, "},{"text":"“Buy less, choose well, make it last”. ","bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Katie Brown is an environmental campaigner and ex-fashion buyer. She is doing her best to learn and share as much as she can about slow fashion. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/slowitdown_baby/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: Saving the Bees
subtitle: Bees keep our agricultural systems alive. India is at the forefront of efforts to keep bees themselves alive.
author: Bindu Gopal Rao
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Bees: can’t live with them, can’t live without them. We might spend a lot of time avoiding their sting, but these creatures - with their exquisite hives and imposing queens - are foundational to ecosystems everywhere. Three quarters of crops across the world "},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.fao.org/3/i9527en/i9527en.pdf","children":[{"text":"depend on pollinators"}]},{"text":", and honeybees are the most important pollinators we have. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The role of bees in pollination cannot be overemphasised; a colony of about 10,000 bees can pollinate a hectare of land, resulting in high agricultural yields. Apart from honey, bees make nectar, beeswax, pollen, propolis and so on. However, bees are at great risk from changing weather patterns - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://thehoneybeeconservancy.org/bees-climate-change/","children":[{"text":"which affect when plants flower"}]},{"text":". If a plant flowers several weeks early, a bee may still be dormant; without the plant’s nectar, bees are less likely to reproduce. And so the cycle of deterioration continues. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In India, several organisations are cropping up to protect bees - helping to reestablish them in greater numbers. In the process, they are guaranteeing financial prosperity for small-scale farmers, and harnessing the properties of the substances bees make to minimise plastic use. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"India needs around 7 million bee colonies to pollinate its key crops. Current estimates of bee colonies are much lower at only 1.5 million, and dwindling – so much so that farmers are having to rent bee colonies from apiaries. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mumbai’s "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.utmt.in/","children":[{"text":"Under The Mango Tree"}]},{"text":" promotes beekeeping to increase agricultural productivity, combining for-profit and not-for-profit structures. Beekeeping support is offered by the organisation and its partners to around 4,000 farmers and their families. For UTMT, tackling poverty and ecological threats go hand in hand. The team help small farmers gain market access, at the same time as ensuring that unsustainable honey hunting practices - which often kill bees - cease. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another organisation, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://hoopoeonahill.com/","children":[{"text":"Hoopoe on a Hill"}]},{"text":", is located in a village near Kodaikanal in Tamil Nadu. Hoopoe consists of a group of women who work together to bring wild honey gathered by the Paliyans, a tribal community of the Palani Hills to customers across the country. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sweet business","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Honey is a delicious byproduct of each organisation’s bee-preservation efforts. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We filter this honey (to remove bits of wax and parts of the combs) and bottle it in glass jars. Besides honey, we also specialise in making a range of products out of beeswax such as candles, balms as well as a unique product called a beeswax wrap”, says Priyashri Mani, Hoopoe on the Hill’s co-founder. “A beeswax wrap in a natural and biodegradable alternative to one time use plastic cling film. It is an excellent way to store food.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595235154/Hoopoe_on_a_Hill_1_ipnng9.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Making beeswax wraps. Image courtesy of Hoopoe on a Hill. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Under the Mango Tree honey is 100% pure; it is not heat-treated, so as to preserve its all-natural components and benefits. It is all single origin - meaning that it can be traced easily back to its source. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Two origins come into play here - geographical and nectar origins.”, says Sujana Krishmamoorthy, executive director of Under the Mango Tree Society. “Geographical origin is seen in our Wildforest Honey, which comes from Tadoba National Park; our Himalayan Flora comes from the foothills of the Himalayas; our Desert Bloom comes from the Rajasthan area. In these cases, bees work on multiple flowers so the honey would have a combination of flavours.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“In the case of the Nectar Origin, bees usually use single flora nectar sources. Bees only move two kilometres from their hive, so they will source nectar from nearby orchards, such as Litchi. Thus, we can say that single origin honeys are the 'single malt' of honey,” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The test for flora origin is carried out via tests that trace the pollen contained in the honey. Nuances in taste, colour and texture originate from the nectar of the flora and vary with geography, temperature, location and humidity. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595235137/Sujana_Krishnamurthy_meenpi.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sujana Krishmamoorthy, executive director of Under the Mango Tree Society. Image courtesy of Under the Mango Tree. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sustainability Matters","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Indian Council of Agricultural Research reports that India needs around 7 million bee colonies to pollinate its key crops. Current estimates of bee colonies in India are much lower at only 1.5 million, and dwindling – so much so that farmers are having to rent bee colonies from apiaries. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Bees preserve the ecological balance and biodiversity of nature. Bees are responsible for the production of several varieties of nuts, berries and fruit, which are a vital food source for wild animals. Honey produced by bees is used as food, not only by humans but also by birds, animals and insects”, says Vijaya Pastala, CEO at Under The Mango Tree."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Bees build elaborate hives; however, they also provide shelter to other insects and animals. If bees were to disappear from our Earth, many, many species of animals and plants which depend on them would vanish as well. Improved agricultural productivity is directly linked to beekeeping.” "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Given that over 75% of the Indian population is engaged in smallholder farming, any intervention in this space can have a far-reaching impact. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Government Impetus","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To help the beekeeping industry, the Government of India has set up the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.indiafilings.com/learn/national-beekeeping-honey-mission-nbhm/","children":[{"text":"National Beekeeping Honey Mission"}]},{"text":". Its aims include ‘implementing harmless apiculture technologies’ and ‘improving the cultivation of food products through cross-pollination’. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As part of this project, Lakshmi Rao - a senior scientist and assistant director at the Central Bee Research and Training Institute - has conceptualised and launched a floral calendar showing area-wide floral distribution. The calendar will help farmers and beekeepers across India plan their beekeeping cycles at optimal locations. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"My main work was to identify the honey by their floral sources, whether it is unifloral (one flower) or multi-floral (multiple flowers), so the source of the honey is known. In this study I found out which flowers have more nectar, when they release pollen and how the bees work,\" says Lakshmi. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After surveying agriculture, horticulture and forestry and identifying the flowers that had been pollinated, she was able to chart the migratory routes of the bees. The project took four years to complete and covers most of the country. It is expected to make pollination significantly more convenient for honeybees, and thus to boost India’s honey generation and its farmers’ income. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"The effort is to naturally route the honeybees to feed on their choicest flowers in the most favourable area,\" senior researchers at CBRTI "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.msn.com/en-in/news/other/pune-based-institute-publishes-e2-80-98floral-calendar-e2-80-99-to-aid-beekeepers/ar-BB10K9sS","children":[{"text":"said in March"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595235101/IMG_20150211_135622_zh7ynf.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of Under the Mango Tree. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Challenge Factor","italic":true,"bold":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, challenges continue. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"\"Beekeepers in India lack technical knowhow and are trained for a very short duration to understand aspects like bee health\", says Lakshmi. \"People are unaware of how to maintain the health of European honeybees, and problems caused by varroa mites can kill the younger bees.\" Apart from labour issues due to low availability of skilled workers, there are also financial problems to contend with. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, given that over 75% of the Indian population is engaged in smallholder farming, any intervention in this space can have a far-reaching impact. And the benefits of bee pollination for farmers? A staggering 50-100% improvement in yields. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It seems like everyone’s a winner – especially with the help of Hoopoe on the Hill, Under the Mango Tree, and Indian government-sponsored initiatives. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"http://www.bindugopalrao.com/","children":[{"text":"Bindu Gopal Rao ","italic":true}]},{"text":"is a freelance writer and photographer based in Bengaluru. Her interests include bird watching and looking for local and unusual angles in any destination. Environment is a cause that is very close to her heart. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/bindugopalrao/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Featured image courtesy of Lakshmi Rao. ","italic":true}]}]

title: COVID-19 must lead to a radical rethink on air pollution
subtitle: Residents of the UK’s big cities know it’s time to face up to this invisible killer
author: Alex Mistlin
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In February 2013, a young girl named "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jul/07/in-the-days-around-ellas-death-there-were-big-spikes-in-air-pollution","children":[{"text":"Ella Kissi-Debrah"}]},{"text":" died aged nine after 27 visits to hospital for respiratory complaints. Her home was just 25 metres from the South Circular Road in Lewisham, London. In 2014, an inquest determined that Ella died due to acute acute respiratory failure and severe asthma. But after new evidence on local pollution levels came to light, that verdict was quashed and the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2019/may/02/ella-kissi-debrah-new-inquest-granted-into-air-pollution-death","children":[{"text":"High Court granted a new inquest"}]},{"text":", which will take place later this year."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"COVID-19 has already killed thousands in the United Kingdom. 45,318 at the time of writing to be precise. But people did not start dying of nasty respiratory illnesses in February 2020. People have been dying premature deaths - because of pollution - for decades. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The death of Ella Kissi-Debrah was a tragedy waiting to happen. This "},{"type":"link","url":"http://theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/aug/31/proof-air-pollution-killed-my-daughter-ella-new-inquest","children":[{"text":"view is shared by her mother"}]},{"text":", now a passionate campaigner for reform on the issue. Her case is clear; levels of NO² in most urban areas of the UK have been illegally high since 2010 and according to NHS Medical Director, Stephen Powis, air pollution contributes to around 40,000 premature deaths every year. Even before COVID-19, Britain’s toxic - "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/apr/01/air-pollution-falling-london-millions-still-exposed","children":[{"text":"and illegal"}]},{"text":" - levels of air pollution represented a permanent public health crisis. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595447147/TELEMMGLPICT000168315219_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqaHVqxy07MatZBwJp4oicTfQYXXuOqxbkqKzBIujJAkk_u9tsby.webp","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ella Kissi-Debrah.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"What’s more, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/13/compelling-evidence-air-pollution-worsens-coronavirus-study","children":[{"text":"evidence is building"}]},{"text":" to suggest that high levels of air pollution worsen the impact of respiratory diseases like COVID-19. This is because long-term exposure to toxic air eventually leads to the development of the same chronic heart and lung conditions that make people particularly susceptible to the onset of COVID-19 – while short-term exposure may irritate the lungs and increase the risk of infection. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The extraordinary lockdown measures enforced by the UK government in recent months provide the template for the policy response required to adequately lower toxicity levels. In this light, the nationwide shutdown can be seen as a significant, if unintended, stride towards reducing air pollution. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/mar/27/coronavirus-uk-lockdown-big-drop-air-pollution","children":[{"text":"Data analysis from the University of York"}]},{"text":" shows reduced levels of pollution - particularly at hotspots such as Marylebone in London - as a result of the imposed restrictions to non-essential travel and industrial activity."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"And indeed, the overall situation is so frustrating because the solutions are so obvious. Policy-makers aren’t struggling for bright ideas; they’ve been unwilling to expend political capital on the issue. This is simply inadequate where a public health emergency as universal as air pollution is concerned. What’s required is radical political action and wholesale legislative change. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595447192/GettyImages-1135759652_yaxpih.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"ULEZ needs to be expanded.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This means expanding London's low and ultra-low emission zones; it means increasing efforts to monitor existing levels of air pollution; and at the end of the day it means restructuring society and the economy to reflect a renewed focus on public health over the ‘growth at all costs’ attitude that has created this dire situation. Sure, these measures might not be the most popular but it’s important to recognise the urgency of this post-COVID moment. Public health will be a key focus for both national and local government for months, if not years, to come. Motorists have lungs, too.
