So do their kids."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For the time being at least, the air we breathe will be cleaner and the streets will be safer as a result. Indeed, some scientists have gone as far as to suggest that the number of premature deaths avoided due to cleaner air "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/mar/17/air-pollution-likely-to-increase-coronavirus-death-rate-warn-experts","children":[{"text":"might outstrip the number of people killed "}]},{"text":"by COVID-19 itself. But as restrictions continue to ease over the coming weeks it’s important that we don’t simply allow toxic air to return to our cities. The "},{"type":"link","url":"https://uk-air.defra.gov.uk/library/reports.php?report_id=1005","children":[{"text":"UK government’s own expert advisors"}]},{"text":" believe that further investigation of the link between dirty air and the pandemic is “urgently required” and may be relevant to how it is managed moving forward. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The impact of COVID-19 has already been devastating but the pandemic has the potential to be a catalyst for positive change. People have been dying painful and premature deaths for years but only now that a novel respiratory disease has brought the world to a standstill are people calling for radical action on air pollution. Without a green recovery, there will be many more preventable deaths from toxic air. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Alex Mistlin is a recipient of the Guardian's prestigious ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/the-guardian-foundation/2019/oct/01/meet-the-scott-trust-bursary-students-201920","children":[{"text":"Scott Trust Bursary","italic":true}]},{"text":" and has bylines in VICE, Huck and the New Statesman. You can follow him on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/amistlin","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: Surfing through sewage
subtitle: In 1990, a group of surfers got together to protest the UK’s unclean beaches. Now they have a new enemy: plastic.
author: Sadia Nowshin
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Of all the experiences that would motivate you to clean up the oceans, surfing through seas of sewage is pretty high up the list. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A community with a dedication to protecting oceans, beaches and wildlife and a determination to persevere with their mission until the natural world is completely clean, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sas.org.uk/","children":[{"text":"Surfers Against Sewage "}]},{"text":"(SAS) has quickly become one of the UK’s most active and successful environmental charities.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The organisation began as a surfing community whose experience in polluted waters included often swimming through raw sewage. Having had enough of the unsafe environment in which they swam, they launched a campaign calling for UK beaches to be held to a higher hygiene standard. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595604634/Surfers_Against_Sewage_Beach_Clean_Perranporth_mmqwic.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Following years of determined campaigning, the community saw a great growth in numbers as more beach-lovers joined the fight. The UK now boasts some of the cleanest beaches in Europe; compared to the 27% of beaches that passed the Bathing Water Directive’s minimum standards in 1990 when the campaign began, in 2016 this rose to a massive 98.5% pass rate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Through cultivating a community with a common mission to clean up the environment, Surfers Against Sewage have volunteer teams in every corner of the country, working to challenge threats to the natural world across the UK. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jessica Morris is one of the six volunteer regional reps based in the London team who “have all had very different backgrounds and relationships with the ocean” but are “all united in our love and passion to protect the ocean and to build a sustainable future”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"She shared the main aspirations of the initiative: “Net-Zero by 2030, End single-use plastic pollution on UK beaches by 2030, 30% of the ocean & all UK marine protected areas to be 'highly Protected' by 2030, and to end sewage discharge into UK bathing waters by 2030!”."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595604800/trash_on_the_beach_txroow.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"However, while SAS will always challenge threats to water quality and have since extended to consider issues of climate change and coastal development, there is a new threat to the seas that they have prioritised: plastic. An estimated 12 million tonnes of litter and plastic enter the world’s oceans every year and for SAS, throwaway plastic is the new sewage polluting the seas. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The collective boasts an impressive record of successes so far: “Over the past year or so we have made some really big leaps in building a community here in London. When I first began as a rep in 2018, we would be lucky to get 10 volunteers coming along to a beach clean. On our last Autumn Beach Clean event we had over 70 people arrive, and over 130 bags of pollution collected!”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"A significant part of the problem faced tends to be the “'out of sight, out of mind' approach” that is common across society, particularly in the capital. With the rapid pace of modern life, people are “very disconnected from their impact on the ocean”. To approach this, SAS’ London team “are working hard to collaborate with as many people, schools, charities and businesses to help educate and invite everyone to make a difference”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Getting involved can be daunting, and not knowing where to start can hold people back from engaging with environmental activism. Jessica emphasised that unity is the key to successfully tackling the problem: “No matter how much or how little you can do, everyone can help. But the key to successfully saving our ocean is to stand together”. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1595604920/skhbgt8x-1465301710_lk6xut.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Though the ecological outlook has become increasingly worrying as our impact on the Earth is revealed, SAS are determined that action can still be taken. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We need the Government to put the environment at the forefront of their policies. We need activists to unite. We need the manufacturers to take responsibility for the amount of pollution they produce. And finally, we need to educate the people. Scientists believe we have only 10 years to save our ocean - there has never been a more urgent time to educate, campaign, and demand change!”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Want to be part of making that change? Follow the team on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/surfersagainstsewage_london/","children":[{"text":"Instagram","italic":true}]},{"text":", ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/sas_london_","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":" and ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/SurfersAgainstSewage","children":[{"text":"Facebook","italic":true}]},{"text":", join a cleanup, sign the #EndSewagePollution ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sas.org.uk/endsewagepollution/","children":[{"text":"petition","italic":true}]},{"text":", or become a ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sas.org.uk/donate/","children":[{"text":"member","italic":true}]},{"text":" to get involved.  ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sadia Nowshin is a Junior Reporter at #ThisMuchIKnow News. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/sadianowshin_","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]}]

title: Food security or oil supremacy?
subtitle: Local-led initiatives are just a temporary salve when it comes to Nigeria’s hunger crisis.
author: Funmi Lijadu
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.globalhungerindex.org/nigeria.html#:~:text=In%20the%202019%20Global%20Hunger,See%20overview%20of%20GHI%20calculation%5D.","children":[{"text":"Global Hunger Index"}]},{"text":", Nigeria is the 24th most hungry out of 114 qualifying countries. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted its existing food security crisis – with some organisations adapting quickly to provide short-term solutions. However, the work of charities like Lagos-based "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/feedikoyi/","children":[{"text":"FeedIkoyi"}]},{"text":" cannot be a substitute for the resolution of wider structural issues. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"FeedIkoyi"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/feedikoyi/","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":", founded by fashion designer Adeju Thompson at the beginning of the pandemic in response to the increased food shortages he anticipated in his local community, distributes packs of free food to the city’s most vulnerable. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" “People really rely on the meals”, said Adeju to "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ASMWoa9BgRc","children":[{"text":"Arise News","italic":true}]},{"text":". “I met someone who said they hadn’t eaten for two days before [FeedIkoyi] came.”"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596013215/Screen_Shot_2020-07-29_at_09.59.53_uampeb.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Meals ready for distribution. Image courtesy of FeedIkoyi. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The initiative has grown from distributing 100 meals a day to feeding close to 1,000 people daily in Ikoyi and Lagos Island. Primarily distributed in the Obalende neighbourhood, these meals have become a lifeline for construction workers, hawkers, petty traders, and day labourers who are jobless during the lockdown. And the charity doesn’t just feed the community – it is also providing Lagosians with jobs, and granting an income to those who might otherwise be unemployed. In April this year, ex-convict Hyacinth Babatubo was employed as part of FeedIkoyi’s staff. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The initiative’s financial support to locals is a critical source of relief at the moment. However, numerous challenges to ensuring food sustainability in Nigeria persist. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the heart of Nigeria’s food insecurity is the nation’s over-reliance on oil revenue. The discovery of crude oil in Nigeria, and the wealth that came from it, led to the agricultural sector being underdeveloped and underfunded. Subsequent rural-urban migration has led to a labour drain from the agricultural industry as young, able-bodied individuals seek opportunities in cities rather than the countryside."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596013369/4560583164_39440b8339_z_nuural.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Oil spills are a big problem. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nigeria has become "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.scirp.org/Journal/PaperInformation.aspx?PaperID=81175","children":[{"text":"‘a major food importing nation’"}]},{"text":" partially because of this. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Nigerian agriculture would do better if nationals were doing most of the processing, packaging and distribution of the food consumed by the public, but this is not currently happening. 2018 saw Nigeria import almost four billion dollars worth of food and drink, perpetuating the underdevelopment of local agriculture. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Pollution is another critical factor. Urbanisation has encroached on land, air and water, and "},{"type":"link","url":"https://allafrica.com/stories/202006290296.html","children":[{"text":"there are on average five oil spills a day in the country "}]},{"text":"– destroying vegetation and agricultural land. A mixture of lack of education on sustainability and inefficient law enforcement means that unsustainable food production and urban waste is mismanaged. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In Northern states, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ft.com/content/02da0292-3268-11e8-b5bf-23cb17fd1498","children":[{"text":"clashes between herdsmen and farmers"}]},{"text":" further limit effective production. Farmers are left devastated and discouraged by frequent violence. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Feedikoyi is an encouraging boost to Nigeria’s food security. Through redistributing food resources to counteract hunger during the pandemic, the initiative is doing very important work - perhaps even saving lives. However, neighbourhood outreach is no substitute for adequate investment and infrastructure – and once things return to ‘normal’, the country’s government has work to do. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596013171/Screen_Shot_2020-07-29_at_09.58.45_ia2owv.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Image courtesy of FeedIkoyi. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Making food accessible to all and doing it sustainably poses a great challenge. As Nigeria’s population continues to rise, so will the severity of its food security challenges and considerations. Community efforts like FeedIkoyi provide much-needed solace and support in the meantime. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://funmi-lijadu.squarespace.com/","children":[{"text":"Funmi Lijadu","italic":true}]},{"text":" is a writer and collage artist highlighting the stories that are less told. She is invested in humanity, the histories that led to our present, and imagining better futures.","italic":true}]}]

title: How green is the UK's new deal?
subtitle: An in-depth look at Rishi Sunak's proposals.
author: Sharlene Gandhi
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As we slowly emerge from the pandemic, and move gingerly towards another, impending recession, Chancellor Rishi Sunak has announced that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/pm-a-new-deal-for-britain","children":[{"text":"£5 billion will be plugged back into the UK’s economy "}]},{"text":"to recover the damage from the coronavirus crisis. The New Deal - likened by Prime Minister Boris Johnson to Franklin D. Roosevelt’s New Deal for the USA following the Great Depression - is an infrastructure-centric recovery plan that will aim to enhance both public and private infrastructure projects, while injecting back into the British economy. The reforms, accompanied by the slogan ‘Build, Build, Build’, will see radical, fast-tracked funding released for ‘shovel-ready’ projects, which allows critical construction and infrastructure to be planned, approved and financed efficiently."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Government has emphasised its desire to “build back better, build back greener, [and] build back faster,” following pressure from "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.carbonbrief.org/coronavirus-tracking-how-the-worlds-green-recovery-plans-aim-to-cut-emissions","children":[{"text":"200 major firms calling for a green recovery"}]},{"text":", and widespread public consensus that COVID-19 presents us with an opportunity to pivot our economy and society towards an eco-centric system. Focus areas include the construction and improvement of public buildings, such as hospitals, schools and prisons, as well as planning for electric vehicle supply chains, charging networks, and ultra-low/zero emissions aircraft. A portion of the budget is also "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.edie.net/registration/regwall.asp?mid=145614&origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eedie%2Enet%2Fnews%2F11%2FDefra%2Dunveils%2Dnatural%2Dcapital%2D%2Dassessment%2D%2Dfunding%2Das%2Dpost%2DBrexit%2Dgreen%2Drecovery%2Dshapes%2Dup%2F&title=Defra+unveils+natural+capital+%27assessment%27+funding+as+post%2DBrexit+green+recovery+shapes+up","children":[{"text":"dedicated to outdoors projects"}]},{"text":", such as reforestation and conservation, in an effort to both improve the UK’s natural environments and preserve jobs in the conservation and forestry sectors. £100 million has also been set aside for research and development into Direct Air Capture (DAC) technology, that aims to ‘suck’ carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere for reuse or permanent storage. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Given that the UK is the first major economy to commit to total decarbonisation/net zero emissions by 2050 in legislation, the economic recovery package aims to be in line with the UK’s 2008 Climate Change Act. Alok Sharma, the Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) has also been appointed as the President of COP26, and so the UK must continue to demonstrate both thought and industrial leadership in the realm of environmental sustainability. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192094/cover102_ncudgj.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Chancellor Rishi Sunak. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How does the economic recovery plan prioritise green growth?","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Heating currently constitutes "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201919/cmselect/cmsctech/287/28702.htm","children":[{"text":"a third of the UK’s emissions"}]},{"text":", making it a critical sector to decarbonise. In July, Rishi Sunak unveiled a "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-53313640","children":[{"text":"£2 billion grant scheme"}]},{"text":" to encourage homeowners to invest in insulation and other energy-saving improvements as part of the COVID-19 recovery plan. The aim would be twofold: not only would homeowners see lowered energy bills, but local special suppliers and tradesmen would also see an uptake in business. The poorest homeowners in the UK will have access to additional funds to undertake this work, but campaigners have also argued that the omission of renters inevitably leaves the poorest out of this deal. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Professor Martin Freer is currently in the process of setting up the National Centre for Decarbonisation of Heat at the University of Birmingham, and believes that “£2 billion is nowhere near the scale required to deliver [low-carbon heat] for 25 to 28 million homes” in the UK. He also highlights the need for funding to be spread across different home energy efficiency solutions, questioning whether “the industry is ready to respond to funding rather than allowing it all to disappear into loft insulation.” Insulation needs to go hand-in-hand with heat delivery from renewables, he points out. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192433/8218016433_2c0eeac15d_b_peih3p.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":" Insulation needs to go hand-in-hand with heat delivery from renewables.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Prioritisation of local growth projects - and thus local jobs - will allow for power and funding to be decentralised, improving ‘local comparative advantage’. Widespread localisation is not only critical to decarbonisation, but also allows for funds to be allocated where issues are most critical, such as in the case of flood defences. Strengthening local economies reduces their reliance on both exports and urban financial centres. Empty commercial properties will be rapidly repurposed in order to support the revival of the local high street, which will in turn reduce the need for new property development on green field lands."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://greennewdealgroup.org/the-green-new-deal-bill/","children":[{"text":"The Green New Deal Group"}]},{"text":" identifies "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/green-bond.asp","children":[{"text":"green bonds"}]},{"text":" as a means to facilitate this critical redistribution of power, whilst "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201919/cmselect/cmsctech/287/28702.htm","children":[{"text":"the Government’s report on Clean Growth"}]},{"text":" spotlights the need for clean energy partnerships between local authorities and private companies to provide affordable energy in local areas. Critical to providing local governments with more funding and resources is an overhaul of the ways in which local government functions, according to Professor Free. Decarbonisation “requires strong collaborations between local government, which either does not have enough funds or is under-resourced, and therefore does not have a chance to think about new and strategic infrastructure.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192611/1200px-Cudworth_-_shops_on_Barnsley_Road_dzdeej.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"High streets need to be regenerated. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"How could the plan be improved from a climate perspective? ","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At present, although the pressing need for a green recovery has been addressed, the UK Government risks paying lip service and even edging into greenwashing territory. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Decarbonisation in certain areas needs to go hand-in-hand with complete divestment from some of the most polluting sectors – fossil fuels being the primary example. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.carbonbrief.org/coronavirus-tracking-how-the-worlds-green-recovery-plans-aim-to-cut-emissions","children":[{"text":"Nigeria and Germany"}]},{"text":", for instance, have outlined targeted COVID recovery plans that centre investment in renewable energy sources, despite the former being a major oil economy. This tension between decarbonisation and divestment is a symptom of a wider problem, whereby a ‘Build, Build, Build’ focus from the UK Government does not do enough to highlight what needs to be cut back. Observations of the UK’s emissions reduction since the 2008 Act have shown that sectors such as transport, heating and agriculture have made little progress thus far; investing heavily in the ‘net new’ or in techno-centric development risks undoing the little progress that has been made from an emissions angle. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Divestment requires relatively radical policy and infrastructural reforms. Alongside fossil fuels, another significant sector needing this reform is aviation. However, alongside oil and gas, the aviation industry has been "},{"type":"link","url":"https://neweconomics.org/2020/06/crisis-support-to-aviation-and-the-right-to-retrain","children":[{"text":"one of the largest recipients of bailout loans"}]},{"text":" from the Bank of England, with British Airways receiving £300 million and EasyJet £600 million. Perhaps even more shocking is the fact that emissions measurements as per the UK’s Climate Change Act currently "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/environmentalaccounts/articles/netzeroandthedifferentofficialmeasuresoftheuksgreenhousegasemissions/2019-07-24","children":[{"text":"does not account for emissions from international air travel"}]},{"text":". If we are already behind target, and still to account for this proportion of our emissions, the alarm is beginning to sound. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192711/unnamed_vhrivn.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Aviation needs reform. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The focus of both the Climate Change Act and subsequent amendments has been largely on heavy polluting industries, with clear "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.wsp.com/en-GB/projects/2050-industrial-decarbonisation-roadmaps","children":[{"text":"decarbonisation roadmaps "}]},{"text":"created for refining, chemicals, iron and steel, cement, ceramics, food and drink, pulp and paper and glass. Financial incentives to decarbonise are, at present, limited to heavy polluting industries. For example, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://ec.europa.eu/clima/policies/ets_en","children":[{"text":"the Emissions Trading Scheme"}]},{"text":" allows each participating enterprise to hold a certain number of carbon credits, gradually decreasing those credits in the run up to 2050, as well as allowing companies to trade credits between themselves. However, other critical industries have been omitted from the decarbonisation journey in the new recovery plan, such as fisheries and agriculture. Agriculture could be shaped up into a solution to the climate crisis – but with farming and unsustainable land use still accounting for both carbon emissions and high water usage, targeted guidance to move British agriculture to a regenerative and innovative industry needs to be prioritised."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In addition, the Government has yet to acknowledge the concept of ‘embedded carbon’, which accounts for emissions over the whole production process of a particular good, primarily the raw materials that go into production. It could be argued, then, that every product produced has an element of embedded carbon, and according to Abbie Morris and James Omisakin of "},{"type":"link","url":"https://compareethics.com","children":[{"text":"Compare Ethics"}]},{"text":", the retail sector is the big elephant in the room. The pair co-run a platform that champions transparency in brands’ supply chains, and believe that “the retail sector is not innovating enough. It contributes to the problem of greenhouse gases, biodiversity loss, and species removal.” Fast fashion is a primary example of where retail slips under the emissions radar; while the products themselves do not emit, the production process is highly polluting and has dire impacts for human wellbeing and rights in garment production factories. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Abbie and James also stress that the service industry has been entirely ignored, despite making up over 80% of the UK’s economy. Services encompass a variety of people and organisations in sectors such as business and management, healthcare, education, consulting, administration, entertainment and property. While services in and of themselves might not be releasing carbon emissions, they either interface with industries that do have high emissions, or are part of supply chains that rely on other forms of environmental damage, such as land damage, water wastage or illegal dumping of toxic waste. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596192978/8249606304_905ef84dd4_b_zh9ywf.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Fast fashion hides a host of human rights and environmental violations. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shifting standards","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://neweconomics.org/2020/07/building-a-green-stimulus-for-covid19","children":[{"text":"The New Economics Foundation"}]},{"text":" reported that a rebound in carbon emissions has already been observed as the economy begins to ramp back up after widespread lockdowns. Professor Freer’s perspective is that the UK Government’s recovery plan “is a signal of intent [towards a green economy], but there is a need to do something more rapidly.” There is, then, a substantial risk that the Government’s recovery plans simply take us back to a pre-pandemic world, rather than taking introspective action to drive sustainable change for a long-term recovery. Industry’s over-reliance on policy to drive environmental action also shows that self-motivation and self-regulation are not reliable options, a sentiment which Abbie and James of Compare Ethics echo: “We need to build a business case for sustainability and raise standards”, they say. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This, firstly, requires a shift in mindset. The Green New Deal Group suggests starting by “ending the fixation on growth.” On a country level, we could follow the footsteps of China to temporarily abandon GDP targets while the economy recovers from the coronavirus, or take a leaf out of New Zealand’s book and abandon GDP targets altogether, in favour of measures that centre people and the environment. On a business level, the model of shareholders and investors expecting bigger and better returns every year also needs to change. The metrics of success need to centre human, social and environmental wellbeing through supply chains, and reinvesting into the business to ensure this is taking place. Similar to Compare Ethics, transparency must become a core value on which companies are judged."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This shift in mindset must, however, be supported by policy to ensure that all businesses in a particular sector, and thus the economy as a whole, are held accountable for their piece in the puzzle. This fundamentally challenges one of the core tenets of capitalism, which is the establishment of competitive markets, because climate change requires collaborative and complementary action. Abbie and James also highlight the inefficacy of auditing as a means of curbing climate emissions: “If [business owners] know when somebody is going to turn up to audit a factory, it leads to inefficient data,” they state. The short-term changes made for an audit or inspection need to be sustained. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596193084/1200px-Kate_Raworth_auditorium_jxyplh.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kate Raworth's 'doughnut model' for economics is a potential path forward. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In addition to sector-specific legislation, reporting requirements, taxation and fines, the Government should move towards incentivising new models of working that actively encourage participative action. "},{"type":"link","url":"https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/bills/cbill/2017-2019/0365/190365.pdf","children":[{"text":"The Decarbonisation and Economic Strategy Bill"}]},{"text":", presented by former leader of the Green Party, Caroline Lucas, outlines the need for “public enterprises, municipal enterprises, worker-owned enterprises, co-operatives, community-owned enterprises, and local private ownership”; so, while the UK’s coronavirus recovery plan touches on localisation initiatives, true decarbonisation is likely to need bottom-up system change through radical democratic and community participation, ensuring adequate wealth redistribution."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Unfortunately, any government’s legislation or economic recovery plan pales against the monolith that is the multinational corporation. Similar to the conundrum of which country should account for the emissions from an international flight, the UK recognises in its climate legislation that it is part of a globalised economy over which it has relatively little control, but still must compete within. This, coupled with the looming threat of Brexit and the recession, means that the UK is unlikely to pass any truly radical legislation, for fear of driving away the international businesses that currently have a home in London - a move labelled "},{"type":"link","url":"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/889037/Government_Response_to_Consultation_on_Future_of_UK_Carbon_Pricing.pdf","children":[{"text":"carbon leakage"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"COVID-19 has brought the world together - although in crisis - and presents us with a rare opportunity to move forward collectively into a more efficient, just and clean world. The UK’s economic recovery plan is sowing the seeds for a long road to green recovery within the borders of the country, but much more has yet to be done by the international business and development worlds. The UK’s role, then, needs to extend to becoming thought leaders and industry leaders in this space, bringing the rest of the world on the journey to sustainability with them. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Sharlene Gandhi is a reporter at ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://couriermedia.co/","children":[{"text":"Courier Media","italic":true}]},{"text":". Her writing focuses on the intersections between sustainability and climate, food/agricultural systems, and responsible corporate business. ","italic":true}]}]

title: Life fosters more life
subtitle: A new school of farmers are regenerating and rewilding land, starting with the soil.
author: Al Howard
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Unless you are a biologist, a farmer or an avid gardener, the topic of soil health may seem uninspiring. With slug pellets and fertilisers available in any nearby garden centre, barren land feels like a problem from a long-lost Biblical past or a George Miller franchise. Yet, advocates of regenerative agriculture have begun to consider farming from the soil up, situating healthy "},{"text":"living","italic":true},{"text":" soil at the heart of all life, and providing a compelling solution to the greatest issues faced by our generation: species extinction and climate change."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The theory is, in principle, simple. By disposing of disruptive practices such as tilling (the digging and overturning of soil) and the use of synthetic fertilisers and pesticides, and by introducing a diverse range of cover crops to protect and nourish the soil, farmers are able to grow better quality food. Perhaps the most significant result of this method is that more carbon can be safely stored in topsoil, reducing the rising levels in the atmosphere. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"At the centre of these studies is a fundamental understanding that life fosters more life; meaning that healthy, living soil provides a natural foundation for a diverse and wholesome food chain. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In recent history we have become aware of the critical effect of consumer culture on the planet, but in even more recent history buzzwords such as ‘sustainability’ have taken a hold. They have been overused and subsequently devalued, leading author and farmer Gabe Brown to ask: “Why would we want to sustain a degraded ecosystem?”. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Consequently, the challenge for many modern farmers is not to merely farm ‘sustainably’, but to rehabilitate their ecosystems and by extension, the soil. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596547025/8053614949_982fecf12d_k_1_ju4ivz.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Farmers are working from the ground up. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Rooted in "},{"type":"link","url":"https://savory.global/","children":[{"text":"Allan Savory’s investigation into holistic management"}]},{"text":" in the 1980s, this approach to farming situates man within the ecosystem, rather than above it. Holistic management aims to recognise the interrelation between man, plants, animals and the land; primarily through the water cycle, the mineral cycle (which includes the carbon cycle), energy flow and community dynamics. Over the past five years, Savory’s "},{"text":"Holistic Management ","italic":true},{"text":"has been developed by Gabe Brown’s book "},{"text":"Dirt to Soil ","italic":true},{"text":"(2018), David Montgomery’s "},{"text":"Growing a Revolution","italic":true},{"text":" (2017) and Graham Harvey’s "},{"text":"Grass Fed Nation","italic":true},{"text":" (2017). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"At the centre of these studies is a fundamental understanding that life fosters more life; meaning that healthy, living soil provides a natural foundation for a diverse and wholesome food chain. Larger insects return as natural predators to eliminate smaller pests; herds of frequently moving animals fertilise the soil; and this in turn resurrects formerly degraded land, allowing wildlife to return."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The founding fathers of regenerative agriculture are so optimistic of its potential for stalling and even reversing the effects of climate change, that you have to wonder – why isn’t everyone doing it?"}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596547778/Screen_Shot_2020-08-04_at_14.29.14_ybji4x.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Lowther Castle, part of the Lowther Estate. Image courtesy of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/p/B31jtZrJJ5V/","children":[{"text":"Lowther Castle","italic":true}]},{"text":". ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"According to Jim Lowther, who runs "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.lowther.co.uk/","children":[{"text":"the Lowther Estate"}]},{"text":" in Cumbria, farmers in the UK have been held back by the scarcity of published results by early practitioners (specifically in terms of soil tests). A second and arguably more pressing issue is the economic risk. As discussed by Gabe Brown, who transitioned to regenerative methods on his North Dakota ranch, soil has often grown reliant on synthetic fertilisers and must undergo a process of weaning, which can be unprofitable and time-consuming. Equally, these new methods are often at odds with those taught by agricultural colleges and practised by past generations of farming families."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim explains that putting regenerative agriculture into practice is achievable, even on a smaller scale, adding that struggling farmers often attempt to counter a poor turnover with more livestock. “It’s a vicious circle that’s difficult to get out of, particularly if there are too many family mouths to feed, all trying to earn a living off a small farm.  In short, they are stuck on a destructive treadmill.” However, with the few who dare to experiment boasting of higher quality harvests and food, more farmers are beginning to convert."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"Whilst the risking of a few years of poor yields will be a bold venture in this fragile economy, the eventual payoff of higher quality food, carbon storage and a lifeline to endangered wildlife is invaluable. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The return of wildlife as a direct result of sustainable farming and conservation has been brought into the limelight by Isabella Tree’s "},{"text":"Wilding: The Return of Nature to a British Farm","italic":true},{"text":". The "},{"type":"link","url":"https://knepp.co.uk/home","children":[{"text":"‘Knepp Experiment’"}]},{"text":" saw the return of doves, nightingales, lesser spotted woodpeckers, purple emperor butterflies, and peregrine falcons to a 3,500 acre estate in West-Sussex. This re-emergence is best understood through the model of the ‘trophic cascade’, whereby the removal of a top predator has a domino effect which reverberates throughout the ecosystem. This theory was demonstrated most strikingly in the reintroduction of wolves at Yellowstone National Park, which restored countless species of flora and fauna, ultimately reshaping the land itself.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim has witnessed changes to his estate after only 18 months. “The simple act of getting rid of the sheep flock and lots of the cattle and stopping farming intensively has allowed the wildlife to come back at a rapid pace”. He adds that the decision to remove their ewes, which was partially driven by economic factors, has also provided ample opportunity to rest the land and enable the growth of trees, shrubs and woodland pasture."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim’s aim is to tackle biodiversity loss and carbon emissions, through planting trees on a grand scale and using electric cars alongside regenerative farming of dairy, beef and crops. ‘Biodiversity’, where a greater variety of plant and animal species co-exist, is fundamental to regenerative agriculture, seeking to rebalance ecosystems which have been dominated by monocropping - where one crop is farmed extensively, reducing the quality of the soil. At Lowther they have started intercropping spring barley and white clover, with the aim of adding in spring beans and peas which “fix nitrogen and provide a good source of protein to milking cows”."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596547979/KneppBurrellweb_3452881b_s6eatl.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Isabella Tree and her husband Charles at the Knepp Estate. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"From North Dakota hailstorms to tropical rains in Ghana, farmers have had to find ways to adapt to extreme weather. At Lowther, they have responded creatively to Cumbria’s past decade of catastrophic flooding. “We’ve done one pond restoration, one floodplain restoration and one beaver release programme.  All of these are designed to slow the flow of water in flood events”. This scheme has also provided a habitat for waders, water voles, otters and a host of wetland plants. However, Jim has found that it is the beavers who are “a keystone species that help to kick start the processes of landscape renewal.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jim operates within a private trust which allows for fast and efficient decision making. However, he acknowledges that Lowther’s food production programmes would not currently be tenable without government subsidy. He has hopes that the transition to regenerative methods will enable the farmland to sustain itself in the future."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The success of regenerative agriculture lies in the commitment of future generations and long-term plans. In a food market which is dominated by low quality corn-fed meat, from overstretched and undernourished farmland, the time has come to make a change. Whilst the risking of a few years of poor yields will be a bold venture in this fragile economy, the eventual payoff of higher quality food, carbon storage and a lifeline to endangered wildlife is invaluable. At its core, regenerative agriculture is a movement which aims to work alongside nature, rather than against it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Originally from Cumbria, Al Howard is a poet and investigative journalist, who studies Art History and English at the University of Glasgow. ","italic":true}]}]

title: Eating for the planet
subtitle: Plant-based eating is having a moment. But is vegan food really more eco-friendly?
author: Chas Newkey-Burden
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Meat-eating environmental activists hate being reminded of the connection between agriculture and climate change – but vegans can be just as defensive when the environmental impact of our lifestyle is pointed out to us."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Everyone knows that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://metro.co.uk/2018/07/18/meat-isnt-just-murder-its-armageddon-why-you-should-become-vegan-now-7732198/","children":[{"text":"switching to a plant-based diet "}]},{"text":"is a good way of reducing your impact on the environment, so the growing popularity of veganism is generally seen as a blessing for the climate change movement. But could it also become a curse?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Vegan life has changed a lot from its fringe days of lentils, nut cutlets and furrow-browed earnestness. It has hit the mainstream. Supermarket shelves are bulging with plant-based imitations of every food type you can name, from doner kebabs to squirty cream. Restaurant chains, fast-food giants and gastropubs all offer plant-based menus. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The tills are ringing as vegans line up to proudly splash their cash on these options. They believe that by doing so they’re proving demand for plant-based food, and thus encouraging suppliers to change their offering to something a little more ethical.Vegan consumerism has succeeded vegan activism and many plant-chompers feel validated and rather pleased as they get to choose from more and more delicious options, while saving animals and the planet."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596818593/neonbrand-SvhXD3kPSTY-unsplash_rusovy.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Shelves are filled with vegan options. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But how many vegan consumers are asking where all these fake meats come from? How did they make these ingredients we can’t even pronounce and how many miles did they travel before they landed on the shelves of our local supermarket? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Is buying locally-produced meat from a small, independent farm less damaging to the environment than buying mass-produced plant-based ‘meat’ that has been wrapped in plastic and flown halfway around the world? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many vegans, myself included, went vegan for the animals rather than for the environment, so the meat option is always off the table regardless of its degree of environmental impact. But that doesn’t mean we can’t dig deeper and ask questions about our choices. We shouldn’t be played by vegan consumerism: stamping a green ‘V’ on a product’s packaging doesn’t mean it was produced angelically. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many of us cheered when Burger King, McDonald’s and KFC started offering vegan burgers, but the profits from these are being plunged back into propping up these chains’ core business: the industrial slaughter of animals and the cheap commodification of their flesh. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Another inconvenient truth is that some vegan staples cause enormous impact. It takes 1,611 US gallons (6,098 litres) "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/food/2018/sep/05/ditch-the-almond-milk-why-everything-you-know-about-sustainable-eating-is-probably-wrong","children":[{"text":"to produce one litre of almond milk"}]},{"text":". Avocados are"},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/avocados-banned-environment-damage-sustainable-cafe-food-cooking-a8663526.html","children":[{"text":" grown on intensive farms "}]},{"text":"that have replaced forests, and are flown in from Central and South America."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Many vegans consume palm oil despite the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://academy.plantbasednews.org/blog/palm-oil-vegan","children":[{"text":"harm that harvesting it has on animals "}]},{"text":"and the huge areas of the rainforest destroyed to make way for the plantations that produce it. If vegans are going to tell people that giving up meat and dairy are simple and obvious steps, shouldn’t we also aim for a more climate-friendly vegan diet? "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596818527/hitoshi-namura-ePsIKxISjNU-unsplash_lc5lqk.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Avocados: hero or villain? ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Thanks to social media, we find ourselves in an age of increasing vanity. People want to feel they have ticked all the ethical boxes so they can tell the world and themselves that they are good people. However, it would be a tragedy if this online plant-based revolution distracted us from impending climate disaster. The idea that vegans are ‘the saviours of the planet’ - that there is no more we can do to help - is damaging. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The connection between the meat industry and environmental destruction is clear. The United Nations says that the animal agriculture industry is"},{"type":"link","url":"https://news.un.org/en/story/2006/11/201222-rearing-cattle-produces-more-greenhouse-gases-driving-cars-un-report-warns","children":[{"text":" responsible for more greenhouse gas emissions "}]},{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://news.un.org/en/story/2006/11/201222-rearing-cattle-produces-more-greenhouse-gases-driving-cars-un-report-warns","children":[{"text":"than the combined exhaust from transportation."}]},{"text":" Methane is 86 times more destructive than CO² and a single cow produces up to 500 litres of methane per day."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Researchers who studied the 35 largest meat and dairy companies found that "},{"type":"link","url":"https://metro.co.uk/2018/07/18/meat-isnt-just-murder-its-armageddon-why-you-should-become-vegan-now-7732198/","children":[{"text":"the top five alone"}]},{"text":" were responsible for more emissions than ExxonMobil, Shell or BP. A separate study concluded that adopting a vegan diet is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://science.sciencemag.org/content/360/6392/987","children":[{"text":"“probably the single biggest way to reduce your impact on planet Earth”"}]},{"text":"."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1596818700/3438077857_cd71665bbf_b_yobgi2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"So yes, if you care about climate change, it's best to stop consuming meat "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/mar/30/dairy-scary-public-farming-calves-pens-alternatives","children":[{"text":"and dairy"}]},{"text":". But - provided you have the time and money to radically change your diet - that should be the beginning, not the end, of your personal revolution. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"We also need to move our attention beyond the personal sphere. We can make other personal changes such as stopping flying, driving less, boycotting fast fashion, and turning down our central heating. But, crucially, these are all individual choices whereas - at the end of the day - climate change requires systemic solutions. We’d be better off demanding those solutions, rather than preening ourselves over our meat-free diets. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Vegans are having our day in the sun but it seems like all that sunshine has gone to some of our heads. We get touchy when people point out the imperfections of our diets. Perhaps that touchiness is telling us something? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/allthatchas","children":[{"text":"Chas Newkey-Burden ","italic":true}]},{"text":"is a writer, nada yogi and animal liberationist. He writes about vegan issues for the Guardian, Independent, Metro, Huffington Post and Attitude. He’s the author of ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.waterstones.com/book/running-cheaper-than-therapy/chas-newkey-burden/9781472948830","children":[{"text":"Running: Cheaper Than Therapy","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]}]

title: “Clean energy is about more than decarbonisation”
subtitle: Addressing racial and economic injustice in California with solar cooperatives.
author: Maggie Gallagher
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Oakland, California is a microcosm of the San Francisco Bay Area’s diversity and divisions. It’s a historic centre of Black culture and progressive activism, but "},{"type":"link","url":"https://datausa.io/profile/geo/oakland-ca/","children":[{"text":"remains deeply segregated along racial and economic lines"}]},{"text":". The mostly-white hills are studded with million dollar homes, while Black and Latino residents are "},{"type":"link","url":"http://m.acphd.org/media/401560/cumulative-health-impacts-east-west-oakland.pdf","children":[{"text":"concentrated in high-poverty neighbourhoods in the flatlands."}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These communities also bear the brunt of the environmental impacts of the Bay Area’s economic prosperity. In East and West Oakland, two neighbourhoods that skirt the edge of the industrial Port of Oakland and are delineated by a maze of eight-lane highways, emergency department visits for asthma attacks are"},{"type":"link","url":"http://m.acphd.org/media/401560/cumulative-health-impacts-east-west-oakland.pdf","children":[{"text":" twice as frequent as in the rest of Alameda County. "}]},{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"http://m.acphd.org/media/401560/cumulative-health-impacts-east-west-oakland.pdf","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Crystal Huang, 32, co-founded "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.peoplepowersolar.org/","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar"}]},{"text":" to address these intertwined problems of environmental degradation, racial discrimination and economic exclusion. Her solution is to empower communities to own clean sources of energy by forming cooperatives that invest in solar installation."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597156792/Screen_Shot_2020-08-11_at_15.39.29_tazhcx.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Crystal Huang.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Crystal has been working in the clean energy industry for over a decade. She says she and others in the field often asked themselves one question: “How do you get low income communities to care about climate change?” But after deepening her engagement with community organisations in the Bay Area, she came to see this as “a question that reflects a lot of ignorance.” “There’s an assumption that they don’t care, and an assumption that it’s their responsibility.” "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This realisation brought on a paradigm shift in her approach to climate action. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“The biggest shift is understanding that, as long as we’re treating the community as consumers, we’re not going to solve the problem,” Crystal says. Instead, People Power Solar approaches people as partners, and as experts in finding solutions to the problems their communities face. The organisation offers legal advice to anyone trying to start a solar cooperative and conducts outreach to community leaders. Ultimately, the power belongs to the people who produce it."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“When communities have control over their source of energy, what they’re doing is investing into their communities,” says Crystal. “Clean energy is about more than decarbonisation. It’s a wealth-building opportunity.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597156909/50190372183_673222e1ca_o_t1posa.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar Cooperative member-owners gathering to set intention for the new year.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In California, the energy generated by privately owned rooftop solar panels is sent back out to the power grid, and the owners are paid for the electricity their panels generate each month instead of receiving an electric bill. As tax incentives for solar installation proliferate and their cost decreases, "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.solarreviews.com/blog/how-to-calculate-your-solar-payback-period","children":[{"text":"rooftop solar panels are paying for themselves "}]},{"text":"more and more rapidly, and becoming a source of profit for their owners."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But before "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.peoplepowersolar.org/projects","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar’s ‘Commons Model’"}]},{"text":", only property owners could reap the financial and environmental benefits of solar power in California."}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“Ultimately the DNA of energy democracy is about people having power literally, financially, and politically.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We disconnect the ownership of land from the ownership of power,” says Crystal. People Power Solar Cooperatives approach local property owners and offer to invest in the installation of solar panels on their rooftops. Once the panels are installed, the owner of the property pays the cooperative for the value of the electricity produced every month and the cooperative distributes the profits to the community members who invested in it initially."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In Oakland, where "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.governing.com/gov-data/census/city-renter-population-housing-statistics.html","children":[{"text":"almost 60% of residents live in rental properties"}]},{"text":", the Commons Model has big implications for the accessibility of solar’s financial benefits. It also offers frontline communities that have been heavily impacted by industrial pollution the opportunity to build their own transition away from fossil fuels. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The movement to expand access to solar is "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.cesa.org/projects/solar-with-justice/","children":[{"text":"gaining traction across the United States"}]},{"text":", with potential effects beyond decarbonisation. Advocates see the solar transition as an opportunity to end dependence on utilities with regional monopolies by putting sources of energy under local control, and to strengthen democratic institutions and political participation in the process. Crystal and other activists call this “energy democracy.” "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597157050/48793899968_733af25c39_o_v85ig2.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Found Anchor Owner, Jessica Tovar, voting at an Annual Member-Owner Meeting.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Ultimately the DNA of energy democracy is about people having power literally, financially, and politically,” says Crystal. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"People Power Solar completed its first project in late 2019, installing panels on the home of Lora Jo Foo, a local activist prominent in the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://nocoalinoakland.info/","children":[{"text":"‘No Coal in Oakland’"}]},{"text":" movement. This pilot project serves as a ‘proof of concept’ that the Commons Model works legally and financially; more than 50 cooperative members are now receiving payments from the project. Through an expansion of this model, according to Crystal, communities can regain control not just over their environmental health but also over their social and economic conditions."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As Crystal says, “The clean energy transition is not about technology alone. Technology is just a tool. Ultimately it’s actually about people.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Maggie Gallagher is based in Berkeley, CA. She graduated in 2018 from UCLA where she was a Lemelson Anthropological Honors Scholar, and spent the past year living and working in Santiago de Chile. She writes about environmental and social issues.","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"All images courtesy of People Power Solar.","italic":true}]}]

title: Fault lines
subtitle: The division of Jammu and Kashmir is damaging an ecosystem that already hangs in the balance.
author: Safina Nabi
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Kashmir region lies at the crossroads of three major human influences – the Persians, the Indus, and the Chinese civilizations; it is nestled at the confluence of the northwestern end of the mighty Himalayas, the Hindu-Kush, and the Karakorum mountain ranges. Known to many as “paradise on Earth”, its location and climate also make it incredibly hazard-exposed – something that has been recently exacerbated by political change in India."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"On 5th August 2019, the Indian government unilaterally scrapped Articles 370 and 35-A, dividing the state of Jammu and Kashmir into two union territories – Jammu Kashmir and Ladakh. A complete communication blockade and curfew was implemented in the area, and troops were deployed. Articles 370 and 35-A had granted semi-autonomous status to the Muslim majority state of J&K after the partition of the subcontinent in 1947. The state had been given authority to establish a separate constitution and state flag; legislate in all matters except finance, defence, foreign affairs and communications; and guarantee property rights to its residents."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Most of the former state falls under a seismic zone V (the highest earthquake prone zone). Ladakh has always been a sensitive Himalayan ecosystem and has experienced natural hazards and disasters of varying scales over the decades. It is also situated on a fault-line of ongoing border disagreements between India, China and Pakistan. Since the scrapping of the articles, there have been signs of further manmade environmental damage."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597565790/Jammu_kashmir_t3mhpd.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"After abolishing semi-autonomous status, the union government passed the Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act in parliament, which came to effect on 31st October 2019. Soon, the UT administration identified over 57,000 acres of land for setting up industrial estates. The imminent land-use changes in the region have caused dismay among common people and environmental activists."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Environmental expert and hydraulic engineer Aijaz Rasool said that “by implementing new laws and diluting the previous environmental laws, the Indian government has made it easy for business houses to get permits for projects that were either rejected or stuck due to non clarification.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“All this is happening in the name of development, without considering the fragile ecosystem of the area.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"India has recently drafted new rules of Environment Impact Assessment and is facing criticism from environmentalists throughout the country. Aijaz believes that this assessment rule - if passed and implemented in Kashmir - could spell disaster in the entire area. Kashmir is the most fragile zone in the Himalayas, much more than any other place in India. Its ecology is already under threat due to the region’s complicated history, tourism, and illegal construction."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As for the residents of Kashmir themselves – their ways of life and agricultural practices have evolved in tandem with the natural landscape. The garment industry relies on organic farming and vegetable dyes, and boats are built at high altitude from sustainable forest cedar wood. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597513243/10434880854_12a8dcc064_b_jhk86t.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Boats are made with sustainable forest wood. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There are concerns that India – home to some of the most polluted cities on Earth – will import artificial and manmade mechanisms into the clean and untouched environs of Kashmir. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There is also a risk that – because of a new domicile law that has made residency rights significantly easier to attain – a large number of new people will purchase land in Kashmir. For Aijaz, this signals impending geographic and demographic change and thus a threat to the natural environment. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Even during British rule, British people were not allowed to acquire land in Kashmir and hence, they started living in houseboats. Brits were ruling India but had no land rights,” he says - emphasising the magnitude of the situation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We will not allow them to pollute our environment. We will contest this in court and at every level.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Safina Nabi is a full-time independent journalist living in Indian Administered Kashmir. She writes about gender, health, human rights, development and culture for publications like Women Under Siege, The New Humanitarian, Himal and BBC Urdu. ","italic":true}]}]

title: Environmentalism for everyone
subtitle: The women of colour making waves in the UK’s environmental justice community.
author: Solidaritree team
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/solidaritree_/","children":[{"text":"Solidaritree","italic":true}]},{"text":" was founded this year by science policy researcher ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/charisejeanine_/","children":[{"text":"Charise Johnson","italic":true}]},{"text":", content creator Lois Donegal","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/loisdonegal/","children":[{"text":"","italic":true}]},{"text":", and recent-graduate graphic designer ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.instagram.com/hye_jpg/","children":[{"text":"Naz Hye","italic":true}]},{"text":". The team describe themselves as a collective working to create an accessible space for, and amplify the work of, BIPOC individuals and organisations in the environmental sector. Ours to Save got in touch with them to find out a bit more about their aims and what they feel is missing amongst environmentalists at the moment. Here’s what they said: ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As a team we are here to fill in the gaps – environmental justice platforms on social media are typically centred on US issues and activism, and tend to speak to a white audience in hopes of educating a predominately white environmental sector. Ultimately, our intention is to join the larger discussion on environmental justice that has gained a stronger foothold in the UK more recently, with a deliberate focus on BIPOC and other groups in the UK that have been historically underrepresented or ignored within the mainstream environmental movement. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As people who have been pushed to the margins by inequitable and unjust societies and policies, we recognise the inherent value of our unique connections to the environment, and aim to create a community where we can share our stories and work within our own networks and spaces."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It all began when Lois was doing her final project for her MA, focusing on the lack of diversity in the environmental sector in the UK. She reached out to the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.facebook.com/groups/pocinnature/","children":[{"text":"PoC in Nature page on Facebook "}]},{"text":"and Charise replied. She’d just moved to London from Washington DC and was feeling uninspired by environmental discourse in the UK. Lois travelled to London to film with her, they got to talking passionately about environmental justice, and in their first ever meeting together, the idea was born. Lois already knew Naz, as they had lived together and were close friends. She seemed like the obvious choice for a graphic designer to help Solidaritree stand out among an expanding sea of social media infographics. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The reality is that environmental discussions and decisions impact us all - some more than others - but it always seems to be the same people dictating the conversation and solutions. Many of us as BIPOC have connections to countries all around the world, where large environmental organisations launch climate offsetting schemes without liaising with the communities that would be impacted. This leads to (as an example) land grabbing and then community displacement. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1597868215/Untitled_design_76_yu6dhy.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"One of Solidaritree's infographics tackles urban greenery. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Back here in the UK, many BIPOC and other underrepresented groups do not have equivalent access to green spaces as compared to their white counterparts, and this does not sit well with us. This is not equity; this is not justice. We have some very big ideas to tackle these issues, from targeted campaigns and community nurturing, to carrying out our own large scale research of environmental organisations in the UK, continuing the work many have done before us, often with few resources and little to no accolades."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Our mission is to raise awareness of the barriers BIPOC, people from low income backgrounds, LGBTQ+, the disabled and the elderly face with regards to accessing the natural environment here in the UK. To help those who work in these spaces trade knowledge on how best to leverage our collective power in order to make real, lasting change. We want to normalise diversity within the outdoors in the UK and shed light on our own personal experiences."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The dream is to host networking events, workshops, webinars and town halls, to meaningfully engage youth, and to empower those who might not typically enter the environmental sector, by providing them with the skills, knowledge and connections to access this area.
